description: On 17th March 2020, the Swiss canton of Neuchâtel sent 50 members of the civil protection to provide assistance in the cantonal EMS ("établissements médico-sociaux", also called "homes"; nursing homes). On 20th May 2020, the canton announced that the civil protection would progressively withdraw its members from the EMS from now on, and up until the month of June. NB: for the sake of the survey, we will consider 1st June 2020 as the end date for this policy (see the wording in the source), i.e. that the civil protection will have withdrawn the totality of its members by 1st June 2020. UPDATE: The original mobilization of the civil protection in the EMS didn't have an end date, but on 20th May 2020, the canton of Neuchâtel announced that the civil protection would withdraw progressively from the EMS from now until the month of June (for the sake of the survey, we will consider that end date as 1st June 2020).

description: As hospital departments in Switzerland are experiencing a massive increase in work as a result of COVID-19, the Swiss Federal Council announces on March 20, 2020 that the application of the Labor Law of 1964 concerning working hours and rest periods is suspended for as long as the exceptional situation requires. However, employers remain responsible for protecting the health of their employees and must in particular ensure that they are given adequate rest periods. UPDATE: On 20. May 2020 the federal council of Switzerland announced that starting with 01. June 2020 the Labor Law of 1964 would be reestablished for the health-care sector, therefore ending the policy that banned the restrictions of the working law in the health-care sector.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: The Canton Schaffhausen in Switzerland opens on March 25, 2020 a center for medical testing of individuals with typical COVID-19 symptoms. This policy is implemented by the public health department of the Canton Schaffhausen. This Center is runned by Schaffhausen' physicians and is supported by the Swiss civil defence and volunteers from the health sector. The testing capacities and contact tracing capacities have been enlarged. UPDATE: The testing capacities and the capacities for contact tracing should be enlargened, the public health department of the canton Schaffhausen said on July 8th. Responsible for the enlargement of the testing capacities is the Task-Force called "Kantonale Abklärungszentrum (KAZ). The opening hours of KAZ have been extended. Furthermore general practitioners and pharmacies are allowed to test people with symptoms. Moreover measures are planned when there might occur a superspreader event.
type_sub_cat: Public Testing Facilities (e.g. drive-in testing for COVID-19)
target_geog_level: One or more geographical or administrative units within one or more countries

description:
Switzerland: On September 25, 2020, the Federal Council decided to change the Narcotic Drugs Ordinance (BetmSV) with effect from September 28. To minimize the risks of infection with COVID-19, patients may be given up to seven daily doses of medical heroin at the institution or may be dispensed at the patient's home by the responsible physician or a person designated by the responsible physician, provided the patient meets strict criteria.
   Normally, patients receiving heroin- or diacetylmorphine-assisted treatment must visit treatment centers at least once a day to receive their drug. However, given the risks of contagion, a pragmatic approach has been used temporarily since the beginning of the pandemic. This has involved increasing the interval between consultations, with good results.
   The Federal Council has decided to formalize this practice and anchor it in law. The amendment will remain in force until December 31, 2021. It also requires that centers providing heroin-assisted treatment submit a quarterly report to ensure adequate monitoring of this practice by the Federal Office of Public Health.
type_text: legalize a pragmatic approach by centers providing heroin-assisted treatment to minimize the risk of contagion: increasing the interval between consultations allowed
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Provincial/State Government,Municipal Government

description: The Canton Swiss of Vaud is preparing its system in order to be able to start vaccinating as soon as the first vaccines are delivered by the Confederation. Mobile teams will be operational from January 11th 2021. Vaccination centers will also be opened in the various regions of the canton. The aim of this strategy is to protect the vulnerable population first. Vaccination will not be compulsory.

They will be in the hospitals of Davos, Ilanz, Poschiavo, Schiers, Scuol, Thusis,Moesa, Chur and St. Moritz. Due to the high storage requirements vaccinations will only be possible in the above mentioned hospitals.

description:
On January 25th, 2020 the Swiss Federal Office of Public Health informed on its webside about a new Coronavirus outbreak in Chine.
The National Reference Center for Emerging Viral Diseases (NAVI) in Geneva is able to detect the new coronavirus by laboratory diagnostics. Suspected cases would be clarified according to the existing guidelines for MERS and, if necessary, treated.
The Head of the Division of Infectious Diseases of the university hospital of Geneva told Swiss public television on January 24: that the test is very simple: a swab is taken from the back of the throat or from the nose with a cotton bud. It would be applied to people coming back from China who present cold-like symptoms that include coughing, fever, muscular pain and breathing difficulties.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On February 27, the Swiss Canton Ticino announces that starting the next day laboratory tests on possible infections are directly carried out in Ticino.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On March 3 2020, the Swiss government announced the new cost allocation for Coronatests starting on March 4 2020. Up to and including March 3, 2020, laboratory analysis for SARS-CoV-2 was not part of the analysis list (AL, Annex 3 of the Krankenpflege-Leistungsverordnung [KLV]). Thus, it was not an obligation of the compulsory health care insurance (OKP). The Epidemics Act (EpG) was applied, which stipulates that if the cantonal doctor (or, in the case of international travelers, the federal government) orders the analysis for SARS-CoV-2 to protect the population, the costs of the laboratory analysis are borne by the ordering authority. Now the costs are covered by health insurance or by the canton, depending on the case.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On March 3, 2020, the Swiss government announced who will be tested for coronavirus starting on March 4 2020. Only individuals with acute respiratory symptoms (e.g., cough, difficulty breathing) and/or fever AND one of the following testing criteria will be tested: 1. severe symptoms, 2. increased risk of complications, 3. health care professionals, 4. nursing home staff. By order of the cantonal doctor, persons without symptoms may also be tested.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On March 3, 2020, the Swiss government announced who will be tested for coronavirus starting on March 4 2020. Only individuals with acute respiratory symptoms (e.g., cough, difficulty breathing) and/or fever AND one of the following testing criteria will be tested: 1. severe symptoms, 2. increased risk of complications, 3. health care professionals, 4. nursing home staff. By order of the cantonal doctor, persons without symptoms may also be tested. This policy ends on March 8 2020 since from March 9 2020 new health testing rules apply. UPDATE: This policy ends on March 8 2020 since from March 9 2020 new health testing rules apply.

description: The Canton Schaffhausen in Switzerland announced that it's hospital prepare a pre-triage to seperate persons with the Coronavirus from persons without the Virus. If the persons are tested positive they are put in Isolationfacilities inside the hospitals. The Canton Schaffhausen implemented this strategy due to the increasing number of positive tested persons in the Canton. This policy starts at March 9th 2020.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries
enforcer: Provincial/State Government,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description:
On March 6, 2020, the Swiss government further specified who should be tested for coronavirus beginning March 9, 2020. To be tested are: Only patients with acute respiratory symptoms (e.g., cough, difficulty breathing) and/or fever AND who meet one of the following test criteria will be tested: 1. severe symptoms, i.e., presence of medical criteria for hospitalization (bi-lateral pneumonia, ARDS ...); 2. persons with increased risk of complications (particularly vulnerable persons - those over 65 years of age; those with hypertension; diabetes; cardiovascular disease; chronic respiratory disease; diseases and therapies that weaken the immune system; cancer); 3. health professionals with direct patient contact working in a health care facility; 4. staff of nursing homes with direct contact with residents/patients.

Temporarily, additional epidemiological criteria may be applied as guidance for testing regarding persons who have respiratory symptoms and fever AND who, in the 14 days prior to symptom onset: a. have been in an affected area outside of Switzerland, b. have had close contact with a confirmed case. Attending doctors may decide to test symptomatic individuals who do not meet these criteria if it is to protect third parties who are particularly at risk.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
On March 10th, the Jura canton in Switzerland announced the conditions for testing eligibility in the province. 

In order to be eligible for testing, one must display respiratory symptoms (cough) as well as a fever and at least one of the following three criteria: presenting severe symptoms requiring hospitalization, being a "vulnerable" population segment or being a healthcare professional working in a healthcare facility.

Individuals who present symptoms but are not vulnerable won't be tested for COVID-19.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description:
On March 10th, the Jura canton in Switzerland announced the conditions for testing eligibility in the province. 

In order to be eligible for testing, one must display respiratory symptoms (cough) as well as a fever and at least one of the following three criteria: presenting severe symptoms requiring hospitalization, being a "vulnerable" population segment or being a healthcare professional working in a healthcare facility.

Individuals who present symptoms but are not vulnerable won't be tested for COVID-19. UPDATE: On May 7th, the Jura canton in Switzerland announced the implementation of new federal rules for COVID-19 testing eligibility. Indeed, it is now recommended that anyone exhibiting COVID symptoms (loss of taste, loss of smell, fever, acute respiratory distress) gets tested.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: According to the announcement of March 12 and in accordance with the BAG recommendations, not all suspected COVID cases are being tested in the Canton of Zug. Tests are only necessary for people who show severe symptoms or have an increased risk of complications. In addition, tests will continue to be carried out on healthcare professionals and staff of nursing homes with mild respiratory diseases. Since March 9, the tests can be carried out in doctors' surgeries in the canton, although advance notification by telephone is mandatory. All other persons who experience symptoms of a possible respiratory disease (cough/respiratory complaints and fever) should stay at home for up to 24 hours after the symptoms have subsided and should only contact their family doctor by telephone or, if he or she cannot be reached, the emergency medical service if their state of health deteriorates.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On March 13, the Swiss Canton Grisons announces that the Federal Office of Public Health does no longer carry out comprehensive tests. Only people with symptoms from risk groups and patients with particularly severe symptoms are tested. This policy is announced together with the declaration of the "extraordinary status" in the Canton.

Patients have to be announced and test will only be provided according to the recommendations of the Federal Office of Public Health.

This Center is runned by Schaffhausen' physicians and is supported by the Swiss civil defence and volunteers from the health sector.

description: On April 16, swiss canton Zurich recommends that with immediate effect all care facilities and nursery homes should test their residents/employees for SARS-CoV-2, if there is one person tested positive: All people on the same ward should be tested.

description: On March 3 2020, the Swiss government announced the new cost allocation for Coronatests starting on March 4 2020. Up to and including March 3, 2020, laboratory analysis for SARS-CoV-2 was not part of the analysis list (AL, Annex 3 of the Krankenpflege-Leistungsverordnung [KLV]). Thus, it was not an obligation of the compulsory health care insurance (OKP). The Epidemics Act (EpG) was applied, which stipulates that if the cantonal doctor (or, in the case of international travelers, the federal government) orders the analysis for SARS-CoV-2 to protect the population, the costs of the laboratory analysis are borne by the ordering authority. Now the costs are covered by health insurance or by the canton, depending on the case. This policy ends on April 21 2020, because on April 22 2020 new rules apply to the coverage of the costs of coronatests. UPDATE: This policy ends on April 21 2020, because on April 22 2020 new rules apply to the coverage of the costs of coronatests.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Until April 21, 2020, the FOPH in Switzerland recommended testing for SARS-CoV-2 in severely symptomatic patients from risk groups, patients with a more severe course, hospitalized patients, or (healthcare) personnel in direct contact with patients. Since April 22, 2020, the sampling strategy for SARS-CoV-2 analysis can now be significantly expanded thanks to sufficient availability of the tests. In particular, it will be possible to test all symptomatic individuals for epidemiological surveillance during the gradual relaxation of protective measures. This policy ends on June 24, 2020, when new Health Testing rules apply.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Since March 4, 2020, health insurers in Switzerland have covered the cost of the Covid test for people with severe symptoms or increased risk of complications; however, the test is not exempt from the deductible. Testing of persons with mild symptoms who do not belong to a risk group are for epidemic surveillance. These costs are borne by the cantons. This will continue to apply from 22 April 2020, but in the case of hospital, nursing and care staff, their accident insurance will now cover the costs of their Covid tests (assumption of costs in principle in accordance with Art. 9 para. 1 UVG). If a person requests laboratory analysis without medical or epidemiological necessity (i.e., does not meet the clinical criteria), then the person must pay the costs themselves.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Until April 21, 2020, the FOPH in Switzerland recommended testing for SARS-CoV-2 in severely symptomatic patients from risk groups, patients with a more severe course, hospitalized patients, or (healthcare) personnel in direct contact with patients.  Since April 22, 2020, the sampling strategy for SARS-CoV-2 analysis can now be significantly expanded thanks to sufficient availability of the tests. In particular, it will be possible to test all symptomatic individuals for epidemiological surveillance during the gradual relaxation of protective measures. Cantonal doctors may, in justified cases, order the testing of asymptomatic persons in hospitals as well as in socio-medical institutions in order to control the spread of the virus (disease outbreaks) within the institution.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

The data collected will allow to estimate the spread of the new Coronavirus in Ticino and to follow its evolution in the coming months, and will therefore be able to contribute to the development and implementation of targeted measures to prevent and control the epidemic in the medium term.

description: On May 8th, the Canton government announced the relaxation of previous health policies such as restrictions on doctor's visits, nursing home visits and other related medical practices. However, in addition screening will heavily increase along with an informational campaign.

description: Until April 21, 2020, the FOPH recommended testing for SARS-CoV-2 in severely symptomatic patients from risk groups, patients with a more severe course, hospitalized patients, or (healthcare) personnel in direct contact with patients.  Since April 22, 2020, the sampling strategy for SARS-CoV-2 analysis can now be significantly expanded thanks to sufficient availability of the tests. In particular, it will be possible to test all symptomatic individuals for epidemiological surveillance during the gradual relaxation of protective measures. Cantonal doctors may, in justified cases, order the testing of asymptomatic persons in hospitals as well as in socio-medical institutions in order to control the spread of the virus (disease outbreaks) within the institution. Update: Starting on May 11 2020 with limited test availibility it is recommended that priority be given those who meet the clinical criteria and are a high-risk person or/and a health personal. UPDATE: With limited test availability, it is recommended that priority be given to testing those who meet the clinical criteria and at least one of the following criteria: Hospitalized individuals regardless of symptom severity; Particularly vulnerable individuals (65 years and older and adults with hypertension, diabetes, cardiovascular disease, chronic respiratory disease, immunosuppression, cancer); (Health) professionals with direct contact (< 2m for > 15 minutes) with patients in hospitals or residents of nursing homes and other socio-medical institutions (e.g., institutions for people with impairments).
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Since March 4, 2020, health insurers in Switzerland have covered the cost of the Covid test for people with severe symptoms or increased risk of complications; however, the test is not exempt from the deductible. Testing of persons with mild symptoms who do not belong to a risk group are for epidemic surveillance. These costs are borne by the cantons. This will continue to apply from 22 April 2020, but in the case of hospital, nursing and care staff, their accident insurance will now cover the costs of their Covid tests (assumption of costs in principle in accordance with Art. 9 para. 1 UVG). If a person requests laboratory analysis without medical or epidemiological necessity (i.e., does not meet the clinical criteria), then the person must pay the costs themselves. This policy ends on May 14 2020, because on May 15 a new cost distribution applies. UPDATE: This policy ends on May 14 2020, because on May 15 a new cost distribution applies.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: As of April 22, 2020, in Switzerland the cost of the Covid test was paid by the canton, health insurance or accident insurance, depending on the situation. In addition, from May 15, 2020, on the military insurance and the employer will pay the cost of the Coronatest, depending on the situation. The cost distribution as of May 15, 2020 is as follows: For symptomatic individuals,... (1) health insurance will cover the costs if the person additionally belongs to a particularly vulnerable group; (2) accident insurance if there is a specific risk of exposure at the workplace; (3) MIlitary insurance if the person is a member of the armed forces, civilian service or civil defense; (4) or the canton if none of these additional points apply. In the case of asymptomatic persons,  ... (1) the canton covers the costs, if it is an explicit order of the cantonal physician; (2) the employer covers the costs, if there is a specific risk of exposure at the workplace; (3) or the person him/herself covers the costs, if none of the previously mentioned criteria apply and the test is carried out at the request of the person concerned. Symptomatic individuals continue to be those with symptoms of acute respiratory illness with or without fever or muscle pain, and those with sudden onset anosmia or ageusia.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Switzerland, Geneva: The Council of the State announced May 28, that tests prescribed by cantonal doctors as well as tests carried out by screening centers on low-symptom individuals will be reimbursed by the canton at 76 francs.

description: The Canton of Zurich, Switzerland, launches a study on immunity to COVID-19 starting on June 8th, 2020. The commissioned research programm "Corona Immunitas" will start a series of three random tests during which around 3000 people in Zurich will be tested on antibodies against the coronavirus.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: As of June 17, 2020, in Switzerland there is a testing strategy for children under 12 years of age. Symptomatic children will be tested (1) as part of the cantonally mandated contact tracing or outbreak investigation; (2) as part of a hospital admission for respiratory illness or fever; (3) in the presence of persistent mild symptoms (excluding fever) and a general condition that would allow school attendance; (4) ultimately, the decision to test rests with the treating doctor together with the parents, based on the recommendations of the FOPH.

description: On June 24, 2020, the Swiss government announced that, as of June 25, 2020, the federal government will cover all costs of coronatests for individuals who meet the sampling criteria (not only symptomatic people anymore, but also asymptomatic persons who have had contact with a Covid-19 case or on the order of the cantonal doctor) and are tested on the order of a doctor. If the requirements are not met, the employer pays the costs if the test is done at the employer's request, or the person him/herself if the test is done at the person's request. Furthermore, serological tests can now be used in addition to PCR tests.

description: On June 30th, the Jura canton in Switzerland announced that people who present symptoms of COVID-19 or anyone who received a notification via the contact-tracing app SwissCovid must get tested for COVID-19. This does not apply to children below 12, unless they have been identified through the contact-tracing app.

description: On 26th June 2020, the Swiss canton of Neuchâtel announced that the Cantonal Service of Public Health would launch two serological testing surveys (antibody tests) in the canton over the month of July. The first survey will target a random sample of 600 people over 18 years old in the cantonal population. The second survey will target 2500 individuals over 18 years old identified by the triage centers as being positive Covid cases between 1st March 2020 and 1st May 2020. Participation in the survey is not mandatory, although the canton strongly encourages all people who will be contacted for the surveys in July to participate. These surveys will help the canton to better understand the spread of the virus and the level of protection of the cantonal population.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description:
Since October 5 2020, the criteria for being tested in the Swiss canton of Vaud are the typical symptoms of COVID-19, namely:

Symptoms of acute respiratory tract disease (cough, sore throat, shortness of breath, chest pain)
Fever, Sudden loss of smell and / or taste
The presence of less typical symptoms (eg, headache, general fatigue, ...), which are more often found in other diseases, needs to be tested only in case of close contact with a case confirmed positive.

In case of doubt and the progression of symptoms, it is recommended to consult a general practitioner, who will decide whether a test is necessary or not.

description: On June 24, 2020, the Swiss government announced that, as of June 25, 2020, the federal government will cover all costs of coronatests for individuals who meet the sampling criteria (not only symptomatic people anymore, but also asymptomatic persons who have had contact with a Covid-19 case or on the order of the cantonal doctor) and are tested on the order of a doctor. If the requirements are not met, the employer pays the costs if the test is done at the employer's request, or the person him/herself if the test is done at the person's request. Furthermore, serological tests can now be used in addition to PCR tests. UPDATE: This policy will end on November 1, 2020, as new rules will come into force on November 2.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On October 28, 2020, the Swiss government announces that antigen tests can now be used in addition to PCR and serological testing as of November 2, 2020. Symptomatic individuals should be tested with a PCR test whenever possible. Rapid antigen testing may be used in limited capacity in symptomatic individuals if the following 4 criteria are met: Symptom onset for less than 4 days; Not a person at risk; Not working in a healthcare setting with direct patient contact; Outpatient treatment. Non-symptomatic individuals can be tested with both rapid antigen testing or PCR testing, after a report of an encounter with a Covid-19 case, or as part of an outbreak investigation and control. Cantonal doctors may also order serologic testing. The costs of the Corona test will continue to be borne by the federal government if the above-mentioned criteria are met (a medical order is no longer required). If the criteria are not met, either the employer (if the test is ordered by the employer) or the person himself/herself (if the test is ordered by that person) will bear the costs.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: As of June 17, 2020, in Switzerland there is a testing strategy for children under 12 years of age. Symptomatic children will be tested (1) as part of the cantonally mandated contact tracing or outbreak investigation; (2) as part of a hospital admission for respiratory illness or fever; (3) in the presence of persistent mild symptoms (excluding fever) and a general condition that would allow school attendance; (4) ultimately, the decision to test rests with the treating doctor together with the parents, based on the recommendations of the FOPH. This policy will expire on November 5, 2020, when new testing rules for children will be implemented the following day. UPDATE: This policy expired on November 5, 2020, when new testing rules for children were implemented the following day.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: The testing strategy with regard to children under 12 years of age will be adapted in Switzerland as of November 6, 2020. For children over 12 years of age, the same testing strategy applies as for adults. The basic rule for symptomatic children under 12 years of age is that the attending doctor makes the test indication in consultation with the parents or the responsible cantonal authorities. Children in poor general health with or without a new fever (> 38.5°C) remain at home and the parents contact their attending doctor to discuss the procedure. A test for COVID-19 should be performed if no other diagnosis is made by the doctor. However, if the child's general condition is good, the child should remain at home for the time being. If any other symptoms of COVID-19 appear, or if the fever or severe cough persists for more than three days, the same procedure as for children in poor general health is followed. Rhinitis and/or sore throat with or without a mild cough without fever do not require testing. Likewise, children are tested as part of the cantonally mandated contact tracing/outbreak investigation or after hospitalization for respiratory illness or fever.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On December 18, 2020, the Swiss government announced new rules related to Corona testing, which will go into effect on December 21, 2020. Newly, the sampling criteria will distinguish between outpatients, inpatients and non-symtpomatic persons. In the outpatient setting for symptomatic persons, a PCR test should be used whenever possible. Antigen rapid tests are possible if all of the following 3 criteria are met: Symptom onset less than 4 days ago; Not a high-risk individual; Not working in a healthcare setting with direct patient contact. In the inpatient setting for symptomatic individuals, a PCR test should be used whenever possible. Rapid antigen testing is also possible if symptom onset was less than 4 days ago. Non-symptomatic individuals, are either being tested by a PCR or antigen testing if it is in the context of an outbreak investigation or with contact with a person with Covid-19. Cantonal offices may also order serological testing. Rapid antigen tests performed on non-symptomatic persons outside the above sampling criteria that are positive must be confirmed immediately by PCR test (the cost of confirmatory analysis is now borne by the federal government). Otherwise, the federal government will continue to cover only the costs for coronatests that meet the sampling criteria above.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On January 18, 2021 the Swiss Canton Grisons announced that there will be mass testings in Saint Moritz on January 19, 2021 from 8am to 6pm. This is a measure initiated by the health department after several mutated COVID-infections were detected.Registration is possible online or on site, but online is recommended. The tests are free for all (citiens and tourists) and NOT mandatory. There will be two test stations (in gyms). Children between the age of 12-18 need a letter of consent. Children from age 5 -12 must be accompanied by their parents. Children under the age of 5 won't be tested.

description:
On February 24, the Swiss Canton Ticino reaffirms the federal list of recommendations of hygienic measures to prevent the spread of the Coronavirus:
-frequent hand washing
- limit touching one's face
- keep distance to sick people
- cough into tissues 
- wear masks only if one is sick
- stay at home in case of flue-symptoms
- avoid health facilities with influenza-like symptoms 
- not take antibiotics, if not prescribed 
- in case of doubt, one should not go to the hospital, but contact the family doctor or call the cantonal or federal hotline
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries
link: Coronavirus, nessuna misura restrittiva in Ticino

description:
Switzerland, Geneva -- Preventive recommendations for general hygiene published on February 26, 2020. Recommendations include: 
- Wash your hands regularly with soap and water, or with a hydro-alcoholic solution.
- Cough and sneeze into a tissue. After use, throw the tissues in a trash can and wash your hands thoroughly with soap and water , or with a hydro-alcoholic solution .
- Cough and sneeze into the crook of the elbow in the absence of a tissue.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description:
In addition to federal regulations, as of March 3, 2020, the Swiss canton of Nidwalden imposed the following requirements on organizers of events with less than 200 participants:
A list of all participants and their contact information must be kept and submitted to the health authorities, sufficient facilities for hand washing must be provided, and an information sheet by the federal health authority must be publicly displayed during the event.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries
enforcer: Provincial/State Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description:
After the first COVID case was detected in the Swiss Canton of Saint Gallen, the cantonal doctor's office has called on the population to adhere the following hygiene measures:
-Avoid shaking hands.

- Wash your hands regularly and properly with soap.

- Avoid touching your face with your hands.

- Sneeze or cough into a tissue or the crook of your arm. Then dispose of the handkerchief in a closed bucket.

- Use paper towels or hot air dryers in public toilets.

- If you have flu-like symptoms (fever, cough, headache and body aches), stay at home and contact your family doctor by telephone.

- Only go to the doctor's practice or the emergency room after registering by telephone.

- Keep your distance from people who are known to be infected with the Corona virus.

- Ventilate your living spaces regularly.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On March 11, the Swiss Canton Ticino introduces sanitary measures in prisons, i.e. social distancing, the provision of disinfectant and 15 cells are reserved for prisoners who would have to quarantine in case they had contact with an infected person.

description: On 12 March the Canton of Zug reminds of the BAG recommendation. In addition to regular hand washing, it is particularly important that sick people consistently stay at home. description: As the protection concepts of some industry associations are not entirely clear, the Canton of Zug, Switzerland, government council has therefore decreed that masks must be worn for all services involving physical contact or where the minimum distance cannot be maintained. This concerns, among others, hairdressing salons, tattoo studios, cosmetic studios or massage parlors. The obligation to wear masks applies to all those present, i.e. both customers and employees. Not covered by these rules are stores or restaurants, as there is no physical contact and the minimum distance can be maintained.

description:
On March 31, 2020 in Switzerland the Governments of Canton Ticino and Canton Grisons reaffirmed the call to second-home owners and tourists to limit their mobility to a minimum and, as far as possible, refrain from moving into their apartments, especially during Easter.
In order to convey this important message, a special leaflet has been created in Italian and German, shared with Ticino Turismo, which will be distributed by the police on the cantonal territory and outside the canton. UPDATE: Originally the Ticino population was asked to reduce travelling, then residents of a second home in Ticino were required to report, now a common urgend appeal of Canton Ticino and Canton Grisons is launched reiterating the invitation to tourists and owners of secondary homes to limit their movements and the occupation of holiday homes to a minimum, especially during the Easter period.

description:
On March 6, 2020 in Switzerland Canton Basel-City the Departement of Health has made recommendations for care homes on how to deal with visitors.
Residents of nursing homes cannot be expected not to receive a visit from their relatives and friends during the expected duration of the spread of the coronavirus. The health department therefore recommends that nursing homes limit visiting times and go through a well-developed health checklist with every visitor. If one question is answered with "yes", the person should be advised to postpone the visit.

description: In the Swiss canton of Zurich, all prison visits, with the exception of pre-trial detention, are prohibited from March 10 until the end of June. Exceptions to this decision are visits by lawyers. Furthermore, inmates in closed custody who are entitled to vacation must postpone their furlough. In return, inmates were given more opportunities to make phone calls and even video calls to relatives. In addition, interrogations and court hearings are now partly conducted by video.

description: On 6th March 2020, the hospital network (RHNe) of the Swiss Canton of Neuchâtel decided to limit visits to patients to close family and partners only. Upon discussion with the doctors in charge, exceptions will also be made for patients reaching the end of their life and for children in the pediatrics department. On 10th March 2020, the canton decided to ban all visits except in 3 cases: 1) for families of people reaching the end of their life 2) for parents of hospitalized children 3) for visits upon request from medical staff. On March 11th, the Jura canton in Switzerland decided to forbid visits to elder people in nursing homes and similar facilities, starting March 12th.

Exceptions are allowed for specific circumstances (situations where the presence of a relative are needed). Flexibility is advised for residents in more critical situations ("end of life situations").

exepted are
walks of around two hours

Visits will only be allowed to residents without confirmed COVID-19 infection and without suspicion of having contracted the virus. In addition care homes will need to have a safety plan complying with health restrictions to limit infections, including clear restrictions on registration, reception, hours and duration of visits, allowed set of individuals for visits, follow up, and hygiene measures.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries
enforcer: Provincial/State Government,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description:
On March 16, 2020 in Switzerland, the canton Aargau decided to ban visits to hospitals and care homes.
Exemptions for end of life situations.
 UPDATE: On May 8, 2020 the Departement of Health and Social Affairs of Swiss Canton Aargau announced that starting May 11 the visiting ban to hospitals and care homes will be replaced by a controlled right to visit provided that adequate protective measures are taken. The institution management determines the exact framework conditions in the form of a visit concept. The hygiene and protective measures must be strictly observed. The responsibility lies with the institution management.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: In the Swiss canton of St. Gallen, visitation of nursing homes and retirement facilities was allowed to resume on May 11, with restrictions. Visitors have to register ahead of time, are only allowed in certain parts of the facilities, and children should be avoided.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On May 7th, the Jura canton in Switzerland announced the resumption of visits in care centers hosting people with disabilities, with respect of sanitary and hygiene measures, for people of their immediate circle. The provincial government, is allowing individual institutions to tailor measures appropriate to their specialties and residents. This measure is effective from May 11th.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: Swiss canton Glarus bans all visitors for care facilities, hospitals and nursery homes on March 13. From May 11, there may be visitors again under observation of certain hygiene measures. UPDATE: From May 11, there may be visitors again under observation of certain hygiene measures.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description:
On March 16, 2020 at an extraordinary meeting the Swiss Federal Council took the decision to introduce more stringent measures to protect the public. It is calling on the elderly in particular to remain at home.  
Covid 19 Ordinance 2, Article 10b: " Principle 1 People at particular risk should stay at home and avoid crowds. 2 People over 65 years of age and people who have the following diseases in particular are deemed to be particularly at risk: high blood pressure, diabetes, cardiovascular diseases, chronic respiratory diseases, diseases and therapies, that weaken the immune system, cancer." (translated)	
 UPDATE: On May 11 the recommandation was eased to "stay at home whenever possible".
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Switzerland, March 14, 2020: The Federal Office of Health issues guidelines on visits to retirement and nursing homes.  Visits by family, friends and acquaintances should be prohibited as far as possible. If this cannot be implemented, the visitors must keep their distance from the residents and strictly adhere to the hygiene rules. Please also note the relevant cantonal guidelines. UPDATE: May 11, 2020, the FOPH : It is important that visits in and outside the institutions should in principle be possible. Visits to particularly endangered residents should be very carefully planned by taking precautions (e.g. asking visitors after COVID- 19 symptoms, transparent barriers, limitation of the number of visitors and the time), so that the distance and hygiene rules are strictly adhered to.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
On March 15, 2020 in Switzerland the government council of Canton Basel - Landschaft decided that visits to hospitals, nursing homes and similar institutions that care for persons from risk groups are prohibited. Exceptions (e.g. visits for patients in extraordinary situations: Parents of children, partners of women giving birth and close relatives of dying people or patients in need of support) are decided by the institution.
This is initially set to last at least till April 30. UPDATE: As of May 11, 2020 relatives will be allowed to visit residents of Basel-Landschaft retirement centers and nursing homes again. The government council has confirmed the relaxation of the visiting ban with its decision of May 5.
Clear rules apply to the visits, which must be followed by all:
    Relatives register for the visit
    Compliance with hygiene and protection measures
    Meeting in specially equipped visiting rooms or visiting boxes
    maximum of 5 persons (incl. resident)
    Registration of visitors
    strict separation of the flow of persons
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: Since May 11, 2020, visits to hospitals, elderly homes, and facilities for people with disabilities in Appenzell Innerrhoden, Switzerland, are allowed under certain conditions, including mandatory registration before the visit, and limited visiting time, while also being limited to specially created visiting zones within the facility. These zones are to be disinfected after each visit. This order is set to at least remain until June 30, 2020. UPDATE: The original restriction on visits to hospitals, elderly homes, or facilities for people with disabilities, has on May 11th, 2020, been lifted under certain conditions.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On June 6th, 2020, the Swiss canton of Appenzell Innerrhoden has further lifted the original restriction on visits to hospitals, elderly homes, and facilities for people with disabilities. Visits do not longer need to be pre-registered, however, all visitors need to register at the entrance, record their personal information, and verify that they do not show any Covid-19 symptoms. Public cafeterias and restaurants within the facilities are allowed to reopen under the condition that they meet the general health advice and guarantee for social distance. UPDATE: The original restriction on visits to hospitals, elderly homes, and facilities for people with disabilities, has on June 6, 2020, been lifted further.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: From March 16, 2020 onwards, the cantonal government of Saint Gallen issues a general ban on visits to nursing homes and retirement facilities. Exceptions can only be made in extraordinary situations (parents of children, death, etc.). UPDATE: From May 11, 2020 onwards, the general ban on visits to nursing homes and retirement facilities was relaxed and visitors are allowed again under strict regulations (prior registration, designated visiting spaces, hygiene and social distancing measures).
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On 6th March 2020, the hospital network (RHNe) of the Swiss Canton of Neuchâtel decided to limit visits to patients to close family and partners only. Upon discussion with the doctors in charge, exceptions will be made for patients reaching the end of their life and for children in the pediatrics department. On 10th March 2020, the canton decided to ban all visits except in 3 cases: 1) for families of people reaching the end of their life 2) for parents of hospitalized children 3) for visits upon request from medical staff. On 14th May 2020, the RHNe added an exception to the list of allowed visits: in the maternity ward, partners / husbands can now accompany their spouses during prenatal examinations and they can now visit their spouses (and the baby) after they have given birth. UPDATE: The original ban on visits in the Neuchâtel hospital network (RHNe) was mandatory with only 3 exceptions (family of dying people, parents of hospitalized children and visits upon request from medical staff). But on 14th May 2020, the RHNe relaxed the compliance of this policy by adding an exception to the list of allowed visits: in the maternity ward, partners / husbands can now accompany their spouses during prenatal examinations and they can now visit their spouses (and the baby) after they have given birth.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description:
On 4th March 2020, the Swiss Canton of Neuchâtel encouraged the EMS ("établissement médico-sociaux"; nursing homes) in the canton to ban, or at least limit visits to residents in order to protect them from coronavirus. It recommends as well that families of residents refrain from visiting their close ones in EMS if they have symptoms or come back from a high-risk region. On 17th March 2020, the cantonal doctor issued a directive banning all visits in EMS, except in cases of emergency (to be assessed by the EMS supervisors). On 23rd April 2020, the cantonal doctor issued a directive reaffirming the ban on visits in EMS, but adding exceptions to this measure. Visits are only allowed in cases of emergency, especially when residents are reaching the end of their life, or when the visit happens in a specific visiting room validated by the cantonal public health office (SCSP). On 20th May 2020, the canton formally announced that visits in EMS would resume shortly (on 25th May 2020), thus ending the original policy.

NB: the date of the 25th May was announced earlier - on 8th May 2020 -, but the definitive measures were only confirmed on 20th May 2020. UPDATE: The original ban on visits didn't have an end date, but on 20th May 2020 the canton of Neuchâtel announced that visits would be allowed again from 25th May 2020 on, thus ending the original policy.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries
compliance: Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)
enforcer: Ministry/Department of Health,Provincial/State Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description:
On 17th March 2020, the Swiss canton of Neuchâtel issued a directive through the cantonal doctor banning all services from external service-providers in EMS ("établissements médico-sociaux"; nursing homes). Only emergency treatments provided by physiotherapists, occupational therapists, chiropractors and osteopaths will be allowed. On 20th May 2020, the canton announced that non-urgent services (hairdresser, podiatrist, chaplaincy, etc...) could be provided again to residents of EMS from 25th May 2020 on, thus ending the original policy.

NB: the date of the 25th May was announced earlier - on 8th May 2020 -, but the definitive measures were only confirmed on 20th May 2020. UPDATE: The original ban on services from external service-providers in EMS had no end date, but on 20th May 2020, the Canton of Neuchâtel announced that these services could be provided again to residents from 25th May 2020 on, thus ending the original policy.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries
compliance: Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)

description:
On 28th of May the Kanton special staff ("Sonderstab") ended the general lockdown of hospitals, elderly homes and homes for the handicappped. But only homes and institutions which require the following conditions are now allowed to reopen:
-they must have a safety concept
-no people who had contact to COVID-19 infected people are allowed in
-only patients who are able to abeit to hygiene and social distancing laws are allowed to leave the instituin or home alone.
If those conditions are not met they are not allowed to reopen. If neccessary, the managements of homes and institutions are allowed to close down again.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On 13th of March 2020 the Uri special staff ("Sonderstab") decreed a visiting ban for the Kanton hospital, all nursing homes, all retirement homes, all homes for the handicapped until 30th of April. Exemptions can be made by the Kanton hospital for partners of parturients, parents, affiliated people of a dying person. The policy was prolonged to 31st of May but ended earlier on 28th of May. UPDATE: The first update of the policy was supposed to last until 31st of May but the policy was already ended on 28th of May.

On July 1, 2020, the restrictions on visits are cancelled completely and nursing/retirement homes may decide on visiting rules themselves.

description: On June 5th, the government of the Swiss Canton of Solothurn announced that hospitals would have to develop a hygiene concept to allow visitors. Minimum requirements include visitor identification and recording, not more than two visitors at shared rooms at a time and visitors following the same hygienic measures as healthcare staff (e.g. wearing masks). The policy was scheduled to start on June 6th.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description:
On March 15, 2020 in Switzerland the government council of Canton Basel - Landschaft decided that visits to hospitals, nursing homes and similar institutions that care for persons from risk groups are prohibited. Exceptions (e.g. visits for patients in extraordinary situations: Parents of children, partners of women giving birth and close relatives of dying people or patients in need of support) are decided by the institution.
This is initially set to last at least till April 30. UPDATE: announced June 2: the government council has lifted the restriction on visits to hospitals, old people's and nursing homes, and homes for the disabled and young people as of June 6, 2020. The institutions are required to develop and implement a specific protection concept that meets the requirements of federal law. A protection concept "opening strategy" for nursing homes was developed by the association CURAVIVA Baselland in close cooperation with the cantonal Office of Health.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On 8th June 2020, the RHNe announced visits could resume under conditions in its centers of Pourtalès and la Chaux-de-Fonds (more generally in all of its centers - see records 2360005 and 8718977 for the other centers)  from 9th June 2020 on. According to the new visiting regime, visits are limited to one visitor per day per patient, for one hour between 3pm and 5pm. The RHNe also added exceptions to this new visiting system: 1) the two parents can visit their children in the pediatrics department 2) the father and the siblings of a newborn can visit the mother and the baby at the maternity ward 3) more visits can be allowed for dying people or patients in intensive care.

This decision will be made on a case-by-case basis, depending on the patient's medical state. The medical team will also decide under which conditions visits are allowed for a patient. Only first-degree relatives will be allowed to visit patients. On 8th June 2020, the RHNe announced a new visiting regime for all of their centers (including la Chrysalide) from 9th June 2020 on: visits are limited to one visitor per day per patient, for one hour between 3pm and 5pm. It also added exceptions to this new visiting system: 1) the two parents can visit their children in the pediatrics department 2) the father and the siblings of a newborn can visit the mother and the baby at the maternity ward 3) more visits can be allowed for dying people or patients in intensive care. UPDATE: The original compliance of this policy was mandatory with exceptions (visits allowed by the medical team). On 8th June 2020, these exceptions were modified and expanded (time and number of visitors restrictions + exceptions for pediatrics department and maternity ward as well as for dying people).

description: From June 29, the health task force of the Swiss Canton of Fribourg requires all care institutions to maintain hygiene and distancing measures, while the systematic control of all entries into the institutions is not required anymore. However, a physical barrier needs to be maintained at the entry and visitors will be traced. Residents are allowed to leave the facilities again as long as they or their relatives are able to abide by the hygiene and behavioural measures, and to identify contacts. Exceptional situations, such as the end of life, immune weakness, minors, etc., will be decided upon individually. The implementation of these measures will be supported by a mobile COVID-Team of care workers, representatives of the care institutions, of the municipalities, and of a doctor who will be in charge.

description: On 28 February, the cantonal management body decides that all cantonal employees should work from home if possible. On 3 July, the canton of Bern, Switzerland, decides to allow cantonal employees to physically return to work. Home office remains an option and is to be decided by supervisors. UPDATE: Cantonal employees should return to work

description:
September 3rd 2020, the Swiss Canton of Fribourg has announced that the Siviriez EMS( nursing home) has a significant number of people positive for COVID-19.

Various measures have been taken by the DSAS
> Temporary stop of visits (except in special situations, such as end of life)
> Collective quarantine of residents and staff. They can however continue to work within the structure.
> Advice via the mobile nurse team and on-site visit
> Authorization to hire additional staff and support the search for staff for the EMS since this search is difficult
> Collaboration with the HFR regarding hospitalizations (reminder: hospitalizations for medical necessity, with the person's consent or advance directives)
> Establishment of psychological support for employees via EMUPS
> Possibility of support for the doctor responsible for the EMS
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description:
On 26th of Feb. 2020 in Switzerland the Government Council of Canton Uri  has set up a special coronavirus staff as part of the cantonal management staff In order to carry out the necessary planning and preparatory work due to the threat caused by the novel Coronavirus. 
The cantonal doctor, the cantonal police, the Office for Civil Protection and the Military, the Education and Culture Directorate and the Landammannamt are represented under the leadership of the Health, Social and Environmental Directorate,  If necessary, the special staff can call in other specialists.

description: In response to measures on march 20 2020, the Cantonal Sport Aid Fund, the Canton of Geneva and the City of Geneva have joined forces to provide an emergency service (Cantonal Sport Aid Fund) in the form of a single online portal specific to the sports sector while also organizing two meetings in the form of online conferences in order to comply with the different semi-confinement measures taken by the Federal Council. Through this platform, the public authorities want to understand the economic consequences linked to covid-19 with regard to the management of associations and/or the organisation of sporting events. The associations concerned will soon have the opportunity to submit an online request for exceptional assistance in order to offset any losses suffered.

description: The government council of the Swiss canton of Zurich decided on April 1, 2020, that extraordinary powers will be transferred to the municipal boards of March 20, 2020. The municipal boards are authorized to adopt commitment credits to mitigate the economic consequences of the coronavirus instead of the municipal parliament. The municipal boards submit the adopted resolutions to the district council. This authorization shall apply as long as the ban on public events pursuant to Art. 6 para. 1 of Ordinance 2 of 13 March 2020 on measures to combat the coronavirus (COVID-19) is in force.

description: On March 22, 2020 in Switzerland the three cantons of Basel-City, Basel-Landschaft and Jura announced that the French Departement Haut-Rhin sent an urgent request for support to the three cantons on March 20. In consultation with the federal authorities, the three governments have agreed that ICU patients from France can be transferred to the cantonal hospitals. Further Swiss cantons ( Aargau, Bern, Fribourg, Geneva, Lucerne, Neuchâtel, Saint Gallen, Schaffhausen, Thurgau, Vaud, Valais, Zurich ) offered help and took ICU patients from French regions Grand-Est and Franche-Comté.

description: On 4th March 2020, the Swiss Canton of Neuchâtel activated the "Etat-major cantonal de conduite (EMCC)" (cantonal general staff) of the ORCCAN (Organisation cantonale de gestion de crise et de catastrophe; Cantonal organization for crisis and disaster management) in relation to the Covid-19 pandemic. The EMCC is able to issue directives to fight the pandemic and to commandeer all workers deemed necessary in that respect (especially health workers, teachers, civil service personnel, public transportation personnel and civil protection personnel). On 26th June 2020, the canton of Neuchâtel announced that the EMCC would switch to a vigil mode only from the month of July on, thus ending the original policy. UPDATE: The original policy fully activated the EMCC, but on 26th June 2020, the canton announced that the EMCC would switch to a vigil mode only, thus ending the original policy.

However, due to the worsening situation in the Canton Swiss, the Cantonal government decided to not follow and closed all construction sites and businesses. description: Switzerland, Geneva -- In response to the crisis caused by the coronavirus, the Department of Economic Development (DDE) is encouraging Geneva restaurants and businesses to develop their offer on the Internet, in order to ensure the supply of the population. As of 25 March, 2020, the DDE has released 100,000 francs to speed up the posting of menus for Geneva restaurants and access to home meal delivery services. This aid is paid in installments to the Société des Cafetiers, Restaurateurs et Hôteliers de Genève (SCRHG), which coordinates the distribution of funds. A fund of 50,000 francs has been allocated to the NODE (Nouvelle Organization Des Entrepreneurs), to strengthen the capacity of local e-commerce platforms to process new requests for integration into their website and thus rapidly increase the number of businesses and products available on the Internet.

description: On March 27, the Swiss Federal Government allowed Cantons under certain circumstances (insufficient capacities, elevated number of cross-border commuters) to temporarily restrict or stop the activity of entire economic sectors as opposed to the federal law. This policy was politicised as "Lex Ticino" as it was tailormade for its case.
type_text: The Swiss Federal Government issued a regulation which allowed Cantons that were especially affected by the pandemic and did not have sufficient resources to close or restrict further certain economic activities, even though the federal law was not restricting them. This policy was mainly targeted at the Swiss Canton Ticino, which decided to keep construction sites closed even though the Federal Government announced to keep them open. The policy thus allows Ticino to go implement stricter measures than the Federal Government.

description:
On 15th April 2020, the Swiss Canton of Neuchâtel created a new organizational system for doctors' offices in order to separate Covid-19 suspect patients from other patients in need of regular medical monitoring. From 20th April 2020 on, 3 networks of doctors' offices are to be distinguished:

1) NETWORK A: only patients without Covid-19 who suffer from a chronic illness or another serious health problem requiring regular medical monitoring

2) NETWORK B (separated in 2 distinct channels): 
a. in the first channel, patients without Covid-19 who suffer from a chronic illness or another serious health problem requiring regular medical monitoring
b. in the second channel, patients suspect or diagnosed with Covid-19

3) NETWORK C: only patients suspect or diagnosed with Covid-19 who are presenting with aggravated symptoms

Patients are to be directed in one or the other network depending on their needs (treatment for chronic illness or Covid-19).
type_text: On 15th April 2020, the Swiss Canton of Neuchâtel created a new organizational system for doctors' offices in order to separate Covid-19 suspect patients from other patients in need of regular medical monitoring. From 20th April 2020 on, 3 networks of doctors' offices are to be distinguished and patients are to be directed in one or the other network depending on their needs (treatment for chronic illness or Covid-19).
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries
enforcer: Ministry/Department of Health,Provincial/State Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description:
The Canton Schaffhausen introduced a mandatory mask wearing for secondary schools (Kantonsschule, Berufsfachschulen, HKV). From August 10 onwards, students, teachers and other personnel have to wear masks inside schools. Exceptions are:
- when there is a minimum distance between people, 
- when there are seperating walls between people,
- teachers don't have to wear masks in frontal teaching classes,
- no mask wearing in sports classes,
- people don't have to wear masks when they are eating in the cantines,
- when people have a medical issue which allows them not to wear masks.

Students, teachers and other personnel have to bring their own masks, but in case the schools have to provide free masks for everyone. 
Furthermore when someone is coming back from a Covid-19 country of risk, this person is obliged to go into quarantine. 
Finally teachers, students and other school personnel have to self-declare that they are informed about the quarantine and mask rules in schools.
type_text: The obligation to wear masks in secondary schools
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries
compliance: Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)

Update: The department of education has strengthened rules in. The new restriction are going to take effect on October 27, 2020. 
-  All teachers and pupils and the parents from primary schools (Volksschule) have to wear masks in the school buildings. 
- School projects such as public events or excursion should not be conducted or attended. 
- Music classes (choirs, bands, singing) is prohibited.
- Sport classes should reduce their participants.
- Excursions are still ok when there is a hygiene concept

On February 24, 2020 the government of Thurgau's Coronavirus Health Unit advices the population to behave according to the recommendations applying for the ordinary flu: (1) wash your hands regularly or use hand sanitizer, (2) sneeze or cough into a tissue; or if you don't have one, into the crook of your arm, (3) avoid contact with people with respiratory problems, and (4) if you experience flu-like symptoms, stay at home.

description: Switzerland, February 27th, The Canton Ticino set up a special hotline for general and sanitary information, as well as for psychological in the context of Covid-19. The number can be reached every day from 7 am to 10 pm free of cost. The questions will be answered by specially trained Civil Protection personnel and supported by professional operators from the Ticino Rescue unit. It is set to avoid overloading the Cantonal Doctor's Office, 144 (medical emergencies) and 117 (police emergencies).

description:
On February 24, 2020 The Swiss Federal government has decided to provide more information to the population  in connection with the coronavirus outbreak. 
Therefore an information campaign for travelers and commuters at the borders and airports was started. A second information campaign on personal protection measures "So schützen wir uns" (Protect yourself and others) is aimed at the general public. In a first step, the FOPH would like to make three important hygiene and behavior rules known: Wash your hands thoroughly, cough and sneeze into a tissue or the crook of your arm, stay at home if you have fever or a cough.

description: On March 3, 2020 the Swiss FOPH announced that the campaign ‘Protect yourself and others’ has been upgraded from yellow to red. In addition to the previous three hygiene rules: Wash your hands thoroughly. Cough and sneeze into a paper tissue or the crook of your arm. Stay home if you have a high temperature and a cough. There are three more rules: Avoid shaking hands. Always call ahead before going to the doctor’s or the emergency department. Dispose of used paper tissues in a sealed waste bin.They apply with immediate effect. Poster and Flyer can be downloaded from the FOPHs webside.

description:
On 26th June 2020, the Swiss canton of Neuchâtel announced a new system to inform the population about the evolution of the pandemic in the canton. Developed by the Cantonal Service of Public Health, this system associates each stage of the pandemic with a color depending on its scale:
- BLUE for a sporadic spread (only a few cases in the canton with no relation with one another)
- YELLOW for a cluster limited to a business, an institution or a defined community
- ORANGE for a localized outbreak within a defined geographical zone
- RED for an exponential progression of the pandemic on the whole cantonal territory

The canton also hereby declared that as of now, the current status of the pandemic in the canton corresponds to the blue stage (sporadic spread).
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries
enforcer: Provincial/State Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description:
On 26th June 2020, the Swiss canton of Neuchâtel announced a new system to inform the population about the evolution of the pandemic in the canton. Developed by the Cantonal Service of Public Health, this system associates each stage of the pandemic with a color depending on its scale:
- BLUE for a sporadic spread (only a few cases in the canton with no relation with one another)
- YELLOW for a cluster limited to a business, an institution or a defined community
- ORANGE for a localized outbreak within a defined geographical zone
- RED for an exponential progression of the pandemic on the whole cantonal territory

The canton also hereby declared that as of now, the current status of the pandemic in the canton corresponds to the blue stage (sporadic spread). On 19th August 2020, the canton of Neuchâtel announced that the progression of the pandemic in the canton now corresponds to the yellow status. UPDATE: The original policy established the blue stage in the canton of Neuchâtel, but on 19th August 2020, the canton announced that the progression of the pandemic in Neuchâtel now corresponds to the yellow stage.

description: The swiss canton Valais starts a new Campaign called "Bliib gsund!" ("Stay in good health!") on September 15 to remind about the safety measures (washing hands, wearing masks...).

target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: September 16th 2020, the Swiss Canton of Fribourg released a public awareness message stating that "You should never throw away your used mask on the street or in nature. After use, it should be disposed in a trash can. You may be fined for non-compliance with this instruction".
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On September 18th, Canton Vaud released several statements detailing the necessary adoption of ad hoc plans and containment measures. Despite this, the Canton insists it is within researched parameters and is seemingly improving the situation.
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On the 28th of September 2020, the Swiss canton of Neuchatel released a public awareness message due to the recent high numbers of Coronavirus cases in the canton. The canton urges people to continue to protect the most vulnerable and respect hygienic measures.
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On October 1st, the Swiss Canton of Vaud announced that it would disseminate graphic posters about COVID as a public safety measure.
type_sub_cat: Both Disseminating and Gathering information related to COVID-19
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: 9th October 2020,  the Swiss Canton of Fribourg shared a public awareness message regarding the Christmas holidays. "In order to be able to celebrate the end of the year holidays in a serene atmosphere, the COVID-19 Coordination Unit looked into the issue and, after consultation with the cantonal doctor, recalls the importance of the health rules in force, in in particular strict respect for distances and barrier gestures. This generally means avoiding contact, providing sufficient space and promoting the organization of events outside ".
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: Starting at Monday Nov. 02 2020 the Canton of Lucerne in Switzerland is launching a new public awareness campaign. The goal of the campaign is to remind the people of hygiene and social distancing measures.
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: Nationwide Committee of Tajikistan’s Health Care and Social Protection Workers Union in cooperation with the ILO Bureau for Workers’ Activities (ACTRAV) in Dushanbe organised a conference “Effects of COVID-19 on Tajikistan’s Health Care and Health Workers. Pandemic Response, Social Dialogue and Policies to Promote Occupational Safety and Health of Tajikistan’s Health Workers at Work”.
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On the 11th of November 2020, the Swiss Federal Office of Public Health made available in most of the migration languages, the main poster of the public awareness campaign "Protect yourself and others". The goal is to share the basics Covid-19 tips to everybody.
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On the 12th of November 2020, The Swiss Federal Office of Public Health released a statement emphasizing on the importance of visiting the "Isolation and Quarantine" website if tested positive or in contact with a person infected by the Corona virus.
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On the 19th of November 2020, the Swiss Federal Office of Health released a video of public awareness about the importance of ventilation. Schoolrooms have to be aired out regularly to reduce the risk of infection, especially now during the coronavirus epidemic. The new video shows schoolchildren how to air out properly.
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: Ministry/Department of Health,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On the 1st of December 2020, the Swiss FOPH released as part of the  public awareness campaign "Protect yourself and others " new printed material. The goal of this action was to state the importance of being tested for Covid-19 if any symptom occurs. The poster also focuses on the fact that tests are free of charge.
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: As part of the  public awareness campaign "Protect yourself and others" the Swiss Federal Office of public health released  on the 9th of December 2020 a new poster showing tips on how to restrain contacts before the Christmas Holidays.
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On December 3rd 2020 the Swiss Federal Office of Public Health announced that on Thursday December 10, a nationwide day (Talk about it, find help) will draw attention to the consequences of the Covid-19 crisis on mental health.
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On Dec. 09 2020 the Social and Health Departement of the canton of lucerne announced that starting at Dec. 10 2020 it will broadcast a tv- and radio-spot to remind the public of the existing hygiene-rules regarding  upcoming christmas-gatherings.
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description:
On the 11th of December 2020, the Swiss Federal Council 
made available a poster summarizing the new dispositions regarding the Coronavirus during the holidays in effort the bring awareness to the situation and spread the rules around the country. Those dispositions are in place until the 22nd of January 2021.
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Provincial/State Government,Municipal Government,Police

description: Following the new dispositions adopted by the Swiss Council of the State of Fribourg, a new hotline has been set up to answer all questions from the population relating to daily life during the Covid-19 pandemic. This hotline is available from the 24th of October 2020.
type_sub_cat: Both Disseminating and Gathering information related to COVID-19
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On February 4, 2020 the Swiss Federal Office of Health recommended on its webside to all persons having returned from China within the last 14 days: If you develop symptoms of a respiratory tract infection (fever, cough, shortness of breath)  stay at home, do not go out in public and contact a doctor immediately, by telephone first.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
The Swiss Federal Office of Public Health informed on its webside for health professionals ( February 17, 2020) that suspected cases (meeting the test criteria) and persons who tested positive for the coronavirus have to be isolated. The cantonal departements of health decide if the person is to be isolated at home or its hotelroom or is transferred to a hospital isolation ward. 
According to some newspapers and cantonal websides the people who tested positive had to be isolated in isolation wards of hospitals.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
On its press conference on February 25, 2020 the Swiss Federal Office of Health informed about the first person in Switzerland confirmed as being infected with the new coronavirus 2019-nCoV. People in close contact with the individual are being notified and placed in quarantine and their condition will be monitored over the next 14 days. On its webside ( February 16) the FOPH informed:" Should there be cases, the sick people would be isolated. Close Contact persons would have to be in quarantine for two weeks."  On the webside for health professionals ( Feb 17) the term close contact is specified:
Contact from less than 2 meters and for more than 15 minutes. People who live in the same household. Care or medical examination without protective gear. Direct contact with body fluids.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
