description: On March 17, 2020 in Switzerland the Government Council of Canton Basel City restricted the use of  public parks, green spaces, squares and the banks of the Rhine. The control of the coronavirus requires everyone to keep their distance from each other, even outdoors. Everyone is urged not to stay for a long time in the recreational areas with large public traffic. Conducting picnics and barbecues is prohibited. Walking or jogging is allowed in the recreation areas. Children with their caregivers may stay in playgrounds. If everyone is considerate of these rules, the parks and public green spaces can remain open.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services
institution_status: This service provided by the government is provided with conditions attached
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description:
On March 20th,2020 in Switzerland the government of canton Jura decided that administrative proceedings for which a public filing is required or for which a conciliation session must be held are suspended. 
This implies that all new public filings must be waived, that opposition periods related to pending public filings cease to run with immediate effect, and that the holding of conciliation sessions is postponed until the measure is lifted. 
The suspension does not apply to proceedings in which the public filing has expired and for which a conciliation session need not be held. In concrete terms, this implies, for example, that the time limit for lodging opposition to a construction project is suspended, since it is not advisable to consult plans with the municipal administration.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services
type_sub_cat: Issuing of permits/certificates and/or processing of government documents
institution_status: This service is no longer provided by the government
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries
compliance: Mandatory (Unspecified/Implied),Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)

description:
On March 20th, 2020 in Switzerland the canton Jura announced that for proceedings before special instances of the administrative jurisdiction (as defined by Article 4, clause 2 of the Code of Administrative Proceedings) and before administrative authorities as per Article 3 of the Code of Administrative Proceedings, all notification of decisions subject to opposition, complaint or appeal  shall be withheld until 30th April 2020.
This means in particular that time limits in civil and administrative proceedings, including cantonal proceedings, are automatically suspended.
However, this measure is not applicable to proceedings concerning the granting of suspensive effect and other provisional measures, nor to time limits set by law. Nor is it applicable to decisions that must be taken imperatively in certain specific situations, such as decisions on conditional release, suspension of sentence and transfer of prisoners. Federal law is reserved.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services
type_sub_cat: Issuing of permits/certificates and/or processing of government documents
institution_status: This service is no longer provided by the government
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On March 20, 2020, the State Council of the Swiss Canton of Geneva, in accordance with the ordinance issued by the Federal Council, decided to temporarily suspend the deadline for collecting signatures and processing popular initiatives and referendum petitions. This is because the collection of signatures in the public space is impossible due to the measures against Covid-19.

description:
On March 20,2020 in Switzerland the Government of Canton Jura decided that all cantonal and communal elections are postponed with immediate effect until further notice.
This also applies when the voting materials have already been distributed to voters e.g. election in Genevez scheduled March 22. In this particular case a new election with new voting material will be organized.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services

description:
On March 20th,2020 in Switzerland the government of canton Jura announced that the processing of cantonal popular initiatives, initiatives of the communes, popular initiatives in the communes as well as optional cantonal and communal referendums is suspended. This implies that the current deadlines, in particular for the collection of signatures and the subsequent processing of these acts are suspended with immediate effect, until further notice. 
Furthermore, the publication in the Official Gazette of new initiatives submitted for signature will be waived.

description: On March 20, 2020, the Swiss canton of Uri decided to freeze the handling deadlines for popular initiatives and the collection deadlines for referenda. The deadlines in connection with cantonal petitions for referendums are suspended until the government council lifts the suspension of deadlines.

description: The government council of the Swiss canton of Zurich decided on April 1, 2020, that extraordinary powers will be transferred to the municipal councils as of March 20, 2020. The municipal boards (Gemeindevorstände) are authorized to adopt commitment credits to mitigate the economic consequences of the coronavirus instead of the municipal assembly (Gemeindeversammlung). The municipal boards submit the adopted resolutions to the district council. This authorization shall apply as long as the ban on public events pursuant to Art. 6 para. 1 of Ordinance 2 of 13 March 2020 on measures to combat the coronavirus (COVID-19) is in force.

Starting from March 20 all non-essential judicial sessions will be suspended until April 19.

description:
On March 20, 2020 in Switzerland the Federal Coucil announced that the following statutory deadlines stand still as of March 21 till may 31:
- Deadline for submitting signature lists for a popular initiative 
- Deadline for the treatment of popular initiatives
- Deadline for the submission of a popular initiative 
The following actions are not carried out during the standstill.
- Disposal of the creation of referenda
- Popular vote on a federal referendum
The collection of signatures is prohibited.

Note that the requests submitted before and on 20th March 2020 will be processed and the respective public inquiries will be carried out.

description: On March 20, 2020 the Swiss Federal Council ordered an extension of the court holidays in civil and administrative proceedings, which are already imminent for the Easter days. In these proceedings, the court holidays start earlier because of the current emergency. They will now last from March 21 to April 19, 2020. This applies in all proceedings under federal or cantonal law. This does not apply to proceedings in which no court holidays are already planned, in particular in urgent matters and criminal proceedings.

description: The Council of State of the Swiss Canton of Fribourg decided on March 31 2020 to impose a standstill on the deadlines for cantonal political rights and political rights at the municipal level (i.e. the deadline for collecting signatures in support of a referendum, a popular initiative and the deadline for the referendum in the case of a mandatory referendum). During this standstill, the collection of signatures and the making available of lists for the collection of signatures is prohibited. This ordinance shall enter into force retroactively to 21 March 2020.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On March 24, 2020, the Swiss canton of Solothurn decides that retroactively from March 21, 2020, the deadlines for cantonal initiatives and referenda will stand still. Accordingly, there is also a ban on collecting signatures during this period. This ordinance shall remain in force for as long as necessary, but for no longer than 1 year from the date of its entry into force. The Government Council shall repeal it in whole or in part as soon as the orders are no longer necessary.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On April 1, 2020, the Swiss canton of Zurich decides that, retroactively from March 21, 2020, a deadline freeze will apply to cantonal and municipal referendum petitions and elections. In concrete terms, this means that for initiatives, among other things, the deadlines for submitting signature lists, for establishing the existence of a popular initiative and for dealing with popular initiatives will stand still. In the case of elections, the deadlines for the submission of election proposals and the examination of election proposals are suspended. During the standstill period, no popular votes on cantonal and communal popular initiatives and no elections shall be held. This Ordinance shall apply for as long as the Ordinance of 20 March 2020 on the suspension of deadlines for federal referendums is in force.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On March 20, 2020, the Swiss canton of Basel City decided that, just as at the federal level, a standstill of deadlines will begin for cantonal referendum petitions as of March 21, 2020. In addition to the collection deadlines, all other deadlines that regulate the handling of referendum petitions are also affected by the present measure. The measure is limited until 31 May 2020.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description:
On March 20, 2020, the Swiss canton of Nidwalden announced that government offices would have to close their counter services to citizens by March 23, if social distancing is impossible to maintain. However, they are still able to handle requests by telephone or e-mail, as well as in person upon appointment.

Essential government offices where social distancing is possible continue to operate their counters at reduced opening hours.

description: The Swiss Canton Grisons holds the June session of the Grand Council as announced on March 23. The session takes place in the Chur town hall and not as usual in the Grand Council building. The town hall is the only space where social distancing can be guaranteed. No audience is admitted to the session, but a live stream will enable all Council negotiations to be followed directly.

description:
On March 19, 2020 in Switzerland the canton of Basel-Landschaft announced that the cantonal police force is temporarily concentrating its post operations at a number of central locations
As of Monday, March 23, 2020 the Allschwil, Therwil, Pratteln, Sissach and Waldenburg sites will be temporarily closed.
The major sites in Liestal, Reinach, Binningen, Muttenz and Laufen remain open.
The provision of police services to the population is fully guaranteed.
On June 24 the reopening as of June 29 was announced.

description: On 25th March 2020, the Swiss canton of Neuchâtel suspended all statutory time limits for submitting requests for referenda and popular initiatives on cantonal and communal matters. Moreover, the canton suspended the issuance of certificates of eligibility to vote ("attestation de la qualité d'électeur") for each request (i.e. the validation of signatures: the administration double-checks that each person who signed the request is eligible to vote and issues a document certifying the number of eligible people who have signed the request). During this suspension, signatures cannot be collected for a prospective petition (referenda or initiatives). The statutory time limits for processing requests is also suspended. All these measures are set to last until 31st May 2020.

target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: The government council of the Swiss canton of Schaffhausen decided on March 24, 2020, that extraordinary powers will be transferred to the municipal councils as of March 25, 2020. The municipal councils are authorized to take financial decisions to protect public order and safety and to avert economic and social emergencies which, according to cantonal and the respective municipal law, fall within the competence of the municipal assembly (Gemeindeversammlung). This authorization shall apply as long as the ban on public events pursuant to Art. 6 para. 1 of Ordinance 2 of 13 March 2020 on measures to combat the coronavirus (COVID-19) is in force.

The deadline for filing the tax return 2019 will be extended from March 31 to May 31. The payment deadline can be extended upon request.
It is advised to handle concerns and questions regarding the submission of the tax return or the tax payment via the Internet, by e-mail or by telephone.

description: On April 1, 2020, the Canton of Bern, Switzerland, announces that it has adopted a deadline freeze for cantonal and municipal "Volksbegehren" (popular petition) due to the coronavirus until May 31, 2020. No signatures may be collected during this period. Unlike popular initiatives, the deadline standstill for the optional referendum applies only conditionally. The time limit is only suspended if there is an interest in suspending the time limit. To prove this interest, it is sufficient for a committee to notify the State Chancellery or the relevant municipal authority of a collection of signatures by April 14, 2020. If no such notification is received, the referendum period continues uninterrupted and uncontested enactments may be enacted after the deadline.

description: On March 31, 2020, the Swiss canton of Graubünden (Grisons) announces a deadline freeze for cantonal initiative and referendum petitions, as well as for referendum petitions in municipalities, municipal associations and regions starting on April 1, 2020 until May 31, 2020 (in accordance with the federal decree). During this standstill, signatures may not be collected, initiatives or referendums may not be submitted and popular votes on initiatives or referendums may not be held.

From March 1 to December 31, 2020, in the event of late payment of the cantonal and municipal tax due in this period, no default interest is due.

For this reason, the government council created a legal framework so that the Cantonal Social Service (KSD) can transfer responsibilities to another social service or another suitable agency if necessary. In individual cases, the competent authority may require that the files must be submitted both in paper form and electronically. In addition, it may, in justified cases, order that files must be inspected digitally and that on-site inspection must be carried out after prior consultation.

type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services
institution_status: This service is no longer provided by the government

description: In Switzerland on April 1, 2020, the canton Aargau implements measures regarding municipal council elections effective April 2. Since municipal assemblies (Gemeindeversammlungen) are currently not allowed to take place, municipalities should be able to hold assembly elections at the ballot box.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On April 1, 2020, the Swiss canton of Aargau decides that from April 2, 2020, the possibilities for silent elections in the election of the municipal council are to be expanded, as there is some uncertainty regarding the conduct of ballots. Admittedly, this only concerns municipal elections. However, cases are already emerging in which a single person is available. In such a constellation, it hardly makes sense to hold ballots at the ballot box at the present time. Voter turnout would probably be very low in view of the fact that the federal government and the canton are foregoing the ballots. If the ballot is postponed, the only person standing for office may be "blocked" for a long time. The policy is valid for 6 months from the effective date. The Government Council cancels it as soon as the measure is no longer necessary.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: In Switzerland on April 1, 2020, the canton Aargau implements measures in order to secure political decisions on municipal level effective April 2. Since currently no more community meetings (Gemeindeversammlungen) may be held, there needs to be another way for a community to pass the necessary resolutions. Therfore, the municipalities may call for a direct vote by the ballot box for matters that cannot be postponed.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description:
On April 3, 2020 in Switzerland the State Chancellery of Canton of Basel-Landschaft has decided that the statutory deadlines for optional referendums will in principle continue to run without a standstill. However, since signatures cannot be collected during the extraordinary situation imposed by the federal government, a standstill of the deadlines can be requested if necessary until May 31, 2020:
- For current referendum deadlines, if it is notified of an ongoing collection of signatures within five days of publication of the government resolution
 -  For future State Council resolutions, the State Chancellery shall suspend the deadlines if it is notified of a planned collection of signatures within five days of the publication of a State Council resolution which is subject to an optional popular vote. 
This applies to cantonal and municipal referenda. No special regulation is necessary for cantonal and communal initiatives, as the cantonal constitution does not stipulate any collection periods for these.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: Switzerland, Geneva--The Counsil of State made amends to voting procedures for the April 5 2020 municipal election as of March 20 2020. description:
On March 20th,2020 in Switzerland the government of canton Jura decided that administrative proceedings for which a public filing is required or for which a conciliation session must be held are suspended. 
This implies that all new public filings must be waived, that opposition periods related to pending public filings cease to run with immediate effect, and that the holding of conciliation sessions is postponed until the measure is lifted. 
The suspension does not apply to proceedings in which the public filing has expired and for which a conciliation session need not be held. In concrete terms, this implies, for example, that the time limit for lodging opposition to a construction project is suspended, since it is not advisable to consult plans with the municipal administration. UPDATE: On April 24th the government of Canton Jura announced that the exceptional regime suspending public filing procedures and the holding of conciliation sessions will end on May 3, 2020. In particular, this implies that the opposition deadlines related to all building permit applications that are subject to public filing as well as those related to land use planning will start running again on May 4, 2020.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services
type_sub_cat: Issuing of permits/certificates and/or processing of government documents
institution_status: This service is no longer provided by the government
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On March 3, 2020, the cantonal government of Fribourg restricts the work of government staff. In order to reduce the risk of infection during rush hours, block hours (normally 8:30am-11:00am and 2:00pm-4:00pm) will be eliminated until further notice. A simplified procedure for home office will apply. Counter service to the public is guaranteed, but individual counter calls are limited to 10 minutes. UPDATE: From May 4, 2020 onwards, starting with the civil services administration, cantonal counter services have started to reopen under strict social distancing measures and prior registration rules. June 2, reopening of the labor service counter,. However, home office and the use of online tools is advised whenever possible.

description: On March 16, 2020 in Switzerland the Federal Council announced that publicly accessible facilities are closed to the public as of March 17 till April 19. This applies as well to public entertainment and leisure establishments, namely museums, libraries, concert halls, theaters, sports facilities, botanical and zoological gardens and zoos. UPDATE: On April 29, the Swiss Federal Council decided that also museums, libraries and archives should be allowed to reopen from 11 May. In these establishments, implementing the rules on hygiene and social distancing is straightforward and it is easy to control people's movements. Botanical gardens and zoos will remain closed.

description: On 16th March 2020, the crisis management task force (ORCCAN) of the Swiss canton of Neuchâtel announced the centralization of police services. From 17th March 2020 on, the public can access police counters in only 3 police stations: Neuchâtel - BAP, La Chaux-de-Fonds - SISPOL and Fleurier. The other police stations will be closed to the public (although some will remain available by phone). On 7th May 2020, the Neuchâtel police added the Hôtel-de-Ville police station to the list of open police counters. This police station will formally reopen to the public on 11th May 2020. Note that the La-Chaux-de-Fonds-SISPOL station won't be used by the police anymore from 11th May 2020 on, i.e. it will remain closed permanently (not for Covid-related reasons). UPDATE: The original policy closed all police counters except Neuchâtel - BAP, La Chaux-de-Fonds - SISPOL and Fleurier, but on 7th May 2020, the Neuchâtel police added the Hôtel-de-Ville police station to the list of open police counters (from 11th May 2020 on).
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On March 17, 2020 in Switzerland the Government Council of Canton Basel City restricted the use of  public parks, green spaces, squares and the banks of the Rhine. The control of the coronavirus requires everyone to keep their distance from each other, even outdoors. Everyone is urged not to stay for a long time in the recreational areas with large public traffic. Conducting picnics and barbecues is prohibited. Walking or jogging is allowed in the recreation areas. Children with their caregivers may stay in playgrounds. If everyone is considerate of these rules, the parks and public green spaces can remain open. UPDATE: Starting May 30, 20202 the ban on picnics and barbecues in public spaces was lifted when the the federal limit of gathering in public spaces was eased from 5 to 30 persons.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services
institution_status: This service provided by the government is provided with conditions attached
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

Walking or jogging is allowed in the recreation areas. Children with their caregivers may stay in playgrounds. If everyone is considerate of these rules, the parks and public green spaces can remain open. UPDATE: Starting May 30, 20202 the ban on picnics and barbecues in public spaces was lifted when the the federal limit of gathering in public spaces was eased from 5 to 30 persons.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services
institution_status: This service provided by the government is provided with conditions attached
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries
compliance: Mandatory with Fines,Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)

description: Switzerland, Geneva--The canton supports the general opening of beaches for the summer beginning May 30. This access is for all of the cantons freshwater sites to allow the population a wide choice as to not overwhelm any particular site. "This opening is done under conditions and is accompanied by a strict respect of the behavior instructions, implying in particular the distance of 2 meters between the people, the respect of the barrier gestures and a limitation of the number of people within the same group. . On all the sites, it is also advisable to adopt the usual rules of good behavior and to take the precautions related to swimming in white water."
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services
institution_status: This service provided by the government is provided with conditions attached
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: In Switzerland, Aargau on March 30, 2020, the cantonal medical service announces with immediate effect the closure of all outdoor sports, recreational and school facilities, because of violations against the federal limit of 5 persons gathering in public spaces. That means that between 8 p.m. and 8 a.m. access to them or being on them during this time is prohibited to ensure complinace to the federal guidelines. UPDATE: With the end of the federal limit of 5 persons gathering in public spaces announced May 27, 2020, all outdoor facilities in Aargau can reopen on May 30.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services
institution_status: This service provided by the government is provided with conditions attached
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description:
On March 20,2020 in Switzerland the Government of Canton Jura decided that all cantonal and communal elections are postponed with immediate effect until further notice.
This also applies when the voting materials have already been distributed to voters e.g. election in Genevez scheduled March 22. In this particular case a new election with new voting material will be organized.
 UPDATE: On April 24,2020 in Switzerland the Government of Canton Jura announced that voting and elections may resume starting June 1st. Therefore this policy ends on May 31, 2020.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services

description:
On March 20th,2020 in Switzerland the government of canton Jura announced that the processing of cantonal popular initiatives, initiatives of the communes, popular initiatives in the communes as well as optional cantonal and communal referendums is suspended. This implies that the current deadlines, in particular for the collection of signatures and the subsequent processing of these acts are suspended with immediate effect, until further notice. 
Furthermore, the publication in the Official Gazette of new initiatives submitted for signature will be waived. UPDATE: On April 24 the government of canton Jura announced that the current suspension of known political rights ( the processing of popular initiatives, referendums ) will end on May 31, 2020 as on federal level.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services
type_sub_cat: Issuing of permits/certificates and/or processing of government documents
institution_status: This service is no longer provided by the government
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On April 7, 2020, the Swiss canton of Schwyz decided that the referendum deadline for resolutions of the cantonal council published after the effective date of this ordinance is suspended. This standstill period ends when the standstill period for federal referendum petitions ends. UPDATE: The standstill period for federal referendum petitions ends on May 31. 2020, therefore this policy ends on that day as well.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On March 24, 2020, the Swiss canton of Solothurn decides that retroactively from March 21, 2020, the deadlines for cantonal initiatives and referenda will stand still. Accordingly, there is also a ban on collecting signatures during this period. This ordinance shall remain in force for as long as necessary, but for no longer than 1 year from the date of its entry into force. The Government Council shall repeal it in whole or in part as soon as the orders are no longer necessary. UPDATE: On May 19, 2020, the government council of the canton of Solothurn decided that the ordinance on the suspension of deadlines for cantonal referendums will be repealed on June 1, 2020. Accordingly, this policy ends on 31 May 2020.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On March 20, 2020, the Swiss canton of Uri decided to freeze the handling deadlines for popular initiatives and the collection deadlines for referenda. The deadlines in connection with cantonal petitions for referendums are suspended until the government council lifts the suspension of deadlines. UPDATE: On May 12, 2020, the Swiss canton of Uri decided to end the deadline freeze for cantonal referendum petitions on May 31, 2020. Accordingly, this Policy will end on May 31, 2020.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On April 1, 2020, the Swiss canton of Zurich decides that, retroactively from March 21, 2020, a deadline freeze will apply to cantonal and municipal referendum petitions and elections. In concrete terms, this means that for initiatives, among other things, the deadlines for submitting signature lists, for establishing the existence of a popular initiative and for dealing with popular initiatives will stand still. In the case of elections, the deadlines for the submission of election proposals and the examination of election proposals are suspended. During the standstill period, no popular votes on cantonal and communal popular initiatives and no elections shall be held. This Ordinance shall apply for as long as the Ordinance of 20 March 2020 on the suspension of deadlines for federal referendums is in force. UPDATE: This policy ends on May 31, 2020, when the national ban on cantonal and municipal elections is lifted and extensions of deadlines related to signature collections, municipal and cantonal referenda and elections are no longer necessary.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description:
On March 23, 2020 in Switzerland Canton Basel Landschaft extended the deadline for tax return for employees from May 31 to June 30, for
self-employed persons and legal entities until 30 September 2020 free of charge.

description: Switzerland, Geneva--The cantonal population and migration office will reopen in a limited capacity beginning June 2. Services will be limited, appointments will be required, and the offices will only be open from 7:30 a.m. until 4:30 p.m. UPDATE: The cantonal population and migration offices were closed March 16 with no date of when they would reopen, it has been announced they will reopen in a limited capacity June 2.

description: On April 29, 2020 in Switzerland the Federal Council decided that starting May 11 botanical gardens and zoos will remain closed, but are expected to reopen on 8 June. UPDATE: From 6 June, the measures put in place to fight the new coronavirus will be extensively eased. That is the decision taken by the Federal Council on 27 May in view of the positive developments in the epidemiological situation. Zoos and botanic gardens, theater and sports facilities may reopen

description: On March 20th, City of Zurich, Switzerland closes several public parks and promenades (Seeuferanlagen / Utoquai, Blatterwiese, Wiese Zürichhorn, Arboretum, Badeanlagen Tiefenbrunnen / Mythenquai, Oberer Letten, Bäckeranlage, Fritschiwiese) as people do not adhere to social distancing. UPDATE: On June 6 all parks are reopened as announced on May 28.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services
institution_status: This service is no longer provided by the government

description: On April 3, 2020, the canton of Thurgau announces that the open day exhibition project "Thurgauer Köpfe" scheduled for April 25, 2020 will be postponed because cantonal museums are currently closed due to the Federal Council decision. UPDATE: On May 8, 2020, the canton of Thurgau announces that the exhibition project "Thurgauer Köpfe" takes place on June 6 since cantonal museums can reopen due to the Federal Council decision from May 11, 2020 onwards.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services
institution_status: This service is no longer provided by the government
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: The government council of the Swiss canton of Zurich decided on April 1, 2020, that extraordinary powers will be transferred to the municipal boards as of March 20, 2020. The municipal boards (Gemeindevorstände) are authorized to adopt commitment credits to mitigate the economic consequences of the coronavirus instead of the municipal assembly (Gemeindeversammlung). The municipal boards submit the adopted resolutions to the district council. This authorization shall apply as long as the ban on public events pursuant to Art. 6 para. 1 of Ordinance 2 of 13 March 2020 on measures to combat the coronavirus (COVID-19) is in force. UPDATE: This ordinance shall be repealed on June 6, 2020. The municipal board has no extraordinary power anymore starting on June 7, 2020.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On 16th March 2020, the crisis management task force (ORCCAN) of the Swiss canton of Neuchâtel announced the centralization of police services. From 17th March 2020 on, the public can access police counters in only 3 police stations: Neuchâtel - BAP, La Chaux-de-Fonds - SISPOL and Fleurier. The other police stations will be closed to the public (although some will remain available by phone). On 7th May 2020, the Neuchâtel police added the Hôtel-de-Ville police station to the list of open police counters. This police station will formally reopen to the public on 11th May 2020. Note that the La-Chaux-de-Fonds-SISPOL station won't be used by the police anymore from 11th May 2020 on, i.e. it will remain closed permanently (not for Covid-related reasons). On 8th June 2020, the Neuchâtel police announced that all police station counters would reopen in the canton, thus ending the original policy. UPDATE: The original policy closed all police counters in Neuchâtel (except 3), but on 8th June 2020, the Neuchâtel police announced that all policy station counters  would reopen in the canton, thus ending this policy.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On March 20th, 2020, the canton of Appenzell Innerrhoden announced that cantonal administration services will only be available online or via phone, while any physical contact within the administration's offices is to be minimized. UPDATE: The original entry had no end date, this policy ends on the 8th of June 2020.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services

description: On March 16, 2020 the canton Nidwalden, Switzerland has announced the closure of its state archives at least until April. The counter services are closed and acess to the reading hall is permitted only in urgent individual cases. UPDATE: On June 8, 2020 the state archives have fully reopened under protective measures. Counter services are now available during regular opening hours. Furthermore, acess to the reading hall is permitted again for a maximum of 4 persons in attendance and with prior regristration.

description: On May 22, 2020, the Swiss canton of Appenzell Innerrhoden decided that since the Lands- and Bezriksgemeinde(n) are cancelled, ballots are held instead. The Extraordinary Ballot Law regulates the procedure for ballots. The law comes into force on June 12. The main election day will thereby continue to be 23 August 2020. Second ballots resulting from the elections of 23 August 2020 will take place on 27 September 2020. With regard to substantive votes, only urgent matters will be voted on. Non-urgent matters will be postponed and will be voted on at the next ordinary Lands- or Bezriksgemeinde.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On 18th March 2020, the Swiss Canton of Neuchâtel decided to postpone the municipal election ("élections communales") that was supposed to take place on 14th June 2020. A new date for the election is still to be chosen and discussed with the municipalities in the canton.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On March 17, 2020, the Swiss canton of Solothurn announced the closure of its government service counters. Requests can only be handled in person upon prior appointment by phone. UPDATE: On June 16, 2020 at the latest, the government service counters in Solothurn have reopend. That day, the Swiss Federal Council has ended the exceptional situation.

description: On March 31, 2020, the Swiss canton of Thurgau decided that by-elections for incompletely filled municipal authorities should not be held as long as there is a ban on events according to Article 6 of COVID19 Regulation 2. The elections are to be postponed to a later date. UPDATE: On June 16, 2020, the Government Council of the Swiss Canton of Thurgau announces that as of June 19, the extraordinary situation according to the Epidemic Law will be terminated. As a result, Ordinance 2 of March 13, 2020 will also be repealed and Article 6 will be terminated. By-elections can be held again in the Canton of Thurgau as of 20 June 2020.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: The government council of the Swiss canton of Schaffhausen decided on March 24, 2020, that extraordinary powers will be transferred to the municipal councils as of March 25, 2020. The municipal councils are authorized to take financial decisions to protect public order and safety and to avert economic and social emergencies which, according to cantonal and the respective municipal law, fall within the competence of the municipal assembly (Gemeindeversammlung). This authorization shall apply as long as the ban on public events pursuant to Art. 6 para. 1 of Ordinance 2 of 13 March 2020 on measures to combat the coronavirus (COVID-19) is in force. UPDATE: On June 19, 2020, Switzerland decided that the COVID-19 Ordinance 2 of March 13, 2020 will be repealed. On June 22, 2020, COVID-19 Regulation 3 will enter into force, so this Policy will end on June 21, 2020.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: From May 12 on the Swiss canton Aargau will reopen all locations of the Museum Aargau in compliance with the federal guidlines on protection concepts. In addition to disinfectants and floor markings for the minimum distance, a limited number of visitors are allowed to enter the premises. Wherever possible, the entrances and exits as well as tours of the museum are separated by direction. Only a few areas in which the distance and hygiene rules cannot be observed remain temporarily closed. UPDATE: This policy ends on June 22, 2020, as the Swiss Federal Council has published guidelines on implementing a precautionary measures plan on June 19.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services
institution_status: This service provided by the government is provided with conditions attached
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description:
On April 21, 2020, the Swiss canton of Graubünden (Grisons) issued an ordinance on extraordinary powers for municipalities. These are authorized to hold ballots instead of municipal meetings (Gemeindeversammlung) for businesses that cannot be postponed. This ordinance is valid as long as the ban on public events according to Article 6 paragraph 1 of the Federal Council Ordinance 2 of 13 March 2020 on measures to combat the coronavirus (COVID-19 Ordinance 2) is in force.

 UPDATE: On June 22, 2020, the new national ordinance of June 19, 2020 will enter into force, thus repealing Article 6 of the ordinance of March 12, 2020. Therefore, this Policy will expire on June 21, 2020.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On April 1, 2020, the Swiss canton of Aargau decides that from April 2, 2020, the possibilities for silent elections in the election of the municipal council are to be expanded, as there is some uncertainty regarding the conduct of ballots. Admittedly, this only concerns municipal elections. However, cases are already emerging in which a single person is available. In such a constellation, it hardly makes sense to hold ballots at the ballot box at the present time. Voter turnout would probably be very low in view of the fact that the federal government and the canton are foregoing the ballots. If the ballot is postponed, the only person standing for office may be "blocked" for a long time. The policy is valid for 6 months from the effective date. The Government Council cancels it as soon as the measure is no longer necessary. UPDATE: On June 24, 2020, the Swiss Canton of Aargau decided that Article 15 on municipal elections in Special Ordinance 1 will be repealed. Thus, this policy ends on June 24, 2020.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On April 1, 2020 the Swiss canton Aargau announces that public spaces can be monitored through cameras by its police from April 2. This is to ensure that the police of Aargau can efficiently control compliance to the federal limit of 5 persons gathering in public in form of a "virtual patrol". UPDATE: As announced on June 24, 2020, Aargau's governing council ends this policy on June 25.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services
institution_status: This service provided by the government is provided with conditions attached
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On April 1, 2020, the Swiss canton Aargau implements measures in the area of public social welfare effective April 2. Due to the pandemic, it is possible that communally or regionally organized social services will no longer be able to perform their duties. For this reason, the government council created a legal framework so that the Cantonal Social Service (KSD) can transfer responsibilities to another social service or another suitable agency if necessary. Futhermore, requests for granting costs for medical purposes that do not tolerate a delay are to be treated as quickly as possible. UPDATE: On June 24, 2020, Aargau's governing council announces the end of this policy effective June 25.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries
enforcer: Municipal Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: In Switzerland on April 1, 2020, the canton Aargau implements measures on municipal level effective April 2. Municipal authorities can now also pass their decisions in the form of digital meetings, such as a telephone conference in order to secure political decisions on municipal level. It should also be possible to elect the municipal council silently in the first ballot. UPDATE: On June 24, 2020, Aargau's governing council announces the end of this policy effective June 25.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services
type_sub_cat: Regulations on government meetings (including e.g. suspension of parliament)
institution_status: This service provided by the government is provided with no conditions attached
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: In Switzerland on April 1, 2020, the canton Aargau decided that the required time limit of 14 days for registration of residents and objects is suspended effective April 2. UPDATE: On June 24, 2020, Aargau's governing council announces the end of this policy effective June 25.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On June 26, the Swiss Canton Ticino implements new health and safety provisions for accessing bathing facilities, precisely public toilets and beaches on the cantonal territory. Every visitor must have at least 7 square meters of space available. At the request of the Cantonal Doctor's Office, the managers must also, if available, immediately provide the contact details of the individual visitors. Those provisions will be valid from 26 June to 31 August.

description:
On March 19, 2020 in Switzerland the government council of Canton Basel Landschaft announced the cancellation of municpal elections and votes scheduled for May 17 and all municipal elections/votes scheduled for June.
The by-elections scheduled for next Sunday ( March 22) can take place.
The term of office for office - holders not already elected on February 9 or March 22, 2020 will be extended until proper renewal elections are held, but not to exceed December 31, 2020. UPDATE: On April 7, 2020 the State Chancellery recommends that the municipalities set aside Sunday, June 28, 2020 as the election date for making up for the cancelled elections which take place by majority voting, in particular the elections of the new mayors and community presidens. For the remaining elections (social welfare authorities, school boards, independent commissions of the municipalities of residents and citizens/burgers, electoral offices), the State Chancellery recommends scheduling them on September 27, 2020, and scheduling the by-elections for November 29, 2020
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: The Swiss Canton Grisons holds the June session of the Grand Council as announced on March 23. The session takes place in the Chur town hall and not as usual in the Grand Council building. The town hall is the only space where social distancing can be guaranteed. No audience is admitted to the session, but a live stream will enable all Council negotiations to be followed directly. UPDATE: On August 11, the Swiss Canton Grisons announces that the August session (25.-28. August) of the Grand Council will also be held in the Chur town hall, as the previous one in June. The same measures regarding the exclusion of the audience, but the provision of live stream apply.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services

description: On 19th August 2020, the Swiss canton of Neuchâtel announced that the maximum number of people allowed inside museums will be limited to 1 person per 8m2 of floor space (staff included). Fines will be given to museums which don't comply with the rules. This measure comes into force on 21st August 2020 and will last until 30th September 2020.

description: On March 25, 2020, the Swiss canton of Nidwalden announced that a referendum on a partial revision of the cantonal tax code scheduled for May 17 would be cancelled and postponed to an unspecified date. UPDATE: On June 23, 2020, the Swiss canton of Nidwalden decided that the cantonal referendum of May 17, 2020 should be held on September 27, 2020. Thus, this policy will then end.

target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On March 24, 2020, the cantonal government of Schwyz announces to postpone the public vote on changes to the "Volksschulen" laws planned for May 17, 2020. UPDATE: The cantonal vote on the partial revision of the Volksschulgesetz has been postponed to September 27, 2020. Thus, this policy ends on September 27, 2020.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On March 20, 2020, the Swiss canton of Thurgau decided to postpone the cantonal referendum of May 17, 2020, on supplementary construction of the government building in Frauenfeld to a later date. By doing so, the canton is reacting to the postponement of the federal referendums. UPDATE: The cantonal referendum in the canton of Thurgau has been postponed to September 27, 2020. Thus, this policy ends on that day.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On March 30, 2020, the municipality (Gemeinde) of Erstfeld in the Swiss canton of Uri also decided to postpone the school building vote of May 17, 2020, like the cantonal and federal votes. The vote is expected to be held on the next official voting date, i.e. Sunday, September 27. UPDATE: On May 28, 2020, the municipality of Erstfeld in the Swiss canton of Uri decided to postpone the school building referendum again, which had been postponed to September 27, 2020, since 11 bills will already be voted on in the canton of Uri on September 27, 2020. The school building vote will now take place on November 29.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On March 20, 2020, the Swiss canton of Uri decided to postpone the popular vote on May 17, 2020 to a later date. The government council will set the voting date in due course. UPDATE: On May 12, 2020, the Swiss Canton of Uri decides that the cantonal referendum will be held together with the federal referendums on September 27, 2020. Thus, this policy ends on September 27, 2020.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On March 18, 2020, the Swiss canton of Aargau decided that the cantonal votes on May 17, 2020 will be postponed to a later date. The canton thus follows the decision of the Federal Council, which has also cancelled the federal votes on May 17, 2020. A new voting date will be set for the submissions at a later date. UPDATE: On May 15, 2020, the Swiss canton of Aargau decided that the cantonal referenda will be voted on together with the federal referenda on September 27, 2020. Thus, this policy ends on September 27, 2020.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description:
On 19th August 2020, the Swiss canton of Neuchâtel announced that the maximum number of people allowed inside museums will be limited to 1 person per 8m2 of floor space (staff included). Fines will be given to museums which don't comply with the rules. This measure comes into force on 21st August 2020 and will last until 30th September 2020. On 10th September 2020, the canton announced that this measure would be extended until 30th November 2020.
 UPDATE: The original policy was set to end on 30th September 2020 and it has been extended to 30th November 2020.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services
institution_status: This service provided by the government is provided with conditions attached
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On October 7, 2020, the Swiss government decided to adopt the Ordinance on the Certification of Votes in Federal Referendums in Times of the COVID-19 Epidemic. The COVID-19 Ordinance on Voting Rights Certification will enter into force on October 8, 2020, and will be valid until December 31, 2021, during which time signatures for optional referendums at the federal level can be submitted to the Federal Chancellery without a voting rights certificate. This means that it will be easier to certify signatures for optional referendums.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On 18th March 2020, the Swiss Canton of Neuchâtel decided to postpone the municipal election ("élections communales") that was supposed to take place on 14th June 2020. A new date for the election is still to be chosen and discussed with the municipalities in the canton. On 4th May 2020, the state council of the Canton of Neuchâtel chose 25th October 2020 as the new date for the election, thus ending the original policy. UPDATE: The original postponement of the municipal election had no end date because the canton of Neuchâtel had not chosen a new date for the election. On 4th May 2020, the canton decided that the election would occur on 25th October 2020, thus ending the policy.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On the 27th of October 2020 the canton of Bern, Switzerland, announced that as of the 27 October 2020, ballots will now be possible in the canton of Bern instead of municipal meetings. The order is valid until 31 January 2021.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On November 3, 2020, the Swiss Canton of Grisons decided that as of November 4, 2020, municipalities are authorized to hold ballots instead of preliminary or final municipal assemblies (Gemeindeversammlungen) if the holding of a municipal assembly is judged to be irresponsible due to the specific COVID-19 situation. In contrast to the spring, the new possibility should no longer exist only for business that cannot be postponed, but for all business. The ordinance is valid until April 30, 2021.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: The Swiss canton of Thurgau announced on November 10, 2020, that municipalities have the option to replace upcoming municipal assemblies (Gemeindeversammlungen) and any council elections with ballot votes. This policy is effective immediately and is limited until March 31, 2021.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On March 20, 2020, the Swiss canton of Basel City decided that the cantonal popular vote of May 17, 2020 will be postponed to a later date. This concerned the cantonal popular vote on the following two proposals: Cantonal popular initiative "Strengthen active Basel youth culture: tip initiative" and Grand Council resolution concerning expenditure approval for the realization of the harbor basin 3. A new date will be arranged at a later date. UPDATE: The rescheduled May 17, 2020 ballot was held on November 29, 2020. Therefore this policy ends on November 29, 2020.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On November 23, 2020, the Swiss Canton of Zurich decided that, as of November 30, 2020, municipal boards (Gemeindevorstände) of assembly municipalities are authorized to order a ballot vote (instead of voting at the local municipal assembly) to set the budget and the tax rate and to approve the annual financial statements. If substantial public interests justify it and there is urgency of time, the municipal councils may also order a ballot vote for other business. This law is valid until March 31, 2021.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On December 11, 2020, the Swiss canton of Lucerne announced that starting from December 12,  libraries and archives, except for lending, museums, public galleries will be closed for the public until January 22, 2021.

description: On December 18, 2020, the government council of the Swiss canton of Bern decided that from December 19, 2020, signature collections on cantonal or communal proposals will be prohibited. Accordingly, the deadlines for submitting a popular initiative or referendum at cantonal and communal level are also at a standstill. This policy is expected to last until January 22, 2021.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: In Switzerland on April 1, 2020, the canton Aargau implements measures in order to secure political decisions on municipal level effective April 2. Therfore, the municipalities may call for a direct vote by the ballot box for matters that cannot be postponed. UPDATE: On June 24, 2020, Aargau's governing council announces that this policy will end on December 31.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: In Switzerland on April 1, 2020, the canton Aargau implements measures regarding municipal council elections effective April 2. Since municipal assemblies are currently not allowed to take place, municipalities should be able to hold assembly elections at the ballot box. UPDATE: On June 24, 2020, Aargau's governing council announces that this policy will end on December 31.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On April 1, 2020, the Swiss canton Aargau implements provisions in the area of public disclosure of files in construction projects effective April 2 until December 31. In individual cases, the competent authority may require that the files must be submitted both in paper form and electronically. In addition, it may, in justified cases, order that files must be inspected digitally and that on-site inspection must be carried out after prior consultation. UPDATE: On June 24, 2020, Aargau's governing council announces that this policy will end on December 31.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services

description: On March 31, 2020, the provincial government announces that urgent referendums in municipalities, school communities and citizen communities can take place as ballot votes as long as the referendums do not require orientation assemblies. Votes on not urgent, complex or disputed issues and replacement votes should be postponed. Postal Voting is advised. UPDATE: On November 10, the Swiss canton of Thurgau announced a renewed possibility to hold referendums instead of municipal assemblies. On this occasion, the order of March 31, 2020, which already allowed for a ballot instead of a municipal assembly for the adoption of resolutions on the 2019 annual accounts and the 2020 budget, is to be repealed with the expiry of the last deadlines extended for this purpose on December 31, 2020.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On May 22, 2020, the Swiss canton of Appenzell Innerrhoden decided that since the Lands- and Bezriksgemeinde(n) are cancelled, ballots are held instead. The Extraordinary Ballot Law regulates the procedure for ballots. The law comes into force on June 12. The main election day will thereby continue to be 23 August 2020. Second ballots resulting from the elections of 23 August 2020 will take place on 27 September 2020. With regard to substantive votes, only urgent matters will be voted on. Non-urgent matters will be postponed and will be voted on at the next ordinary Lands- or Bezriksgemeinde. UPDATE: This law was intended for the year 2020. On February 16, 2021, a new law was enacted for the year 2021, thus ending this policy on February 15, 2021.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: The Swiss canton of Appenzell Innerrhoden decided on February 16, 2021, that the Land and Bezirksgemeinde (i.e. voting in person instead of by hand) will be replaced by ballots in the year 2021. The cantonal ballot will take place on May 9, 2021, and the district ballot on May 16. Second ballots and any supplementary elections of the canton and the districts will be held on June 27, 2021.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: The Swiss canton of Thurgau announced on November 10, 2020, that municipalities have the option to replace upcoming municipal assemblies (Gemeindeversammlungen) and any council elections with ballot votes. This policy is effective immediately and is limited until March 31, 2021. UPDATE: On March 2, 2021, the Swiss canton of Thurgau decided to prolong the possibility of postponing municipal meetings to the ballot box. This decision is limited until July 4, 2021.

If substantial public interests justify it and there is urgency of time, the municipal councils may also order a ballot vote for other business. This law is valid until March 31, 2021. description: Since early April, the Horgen prison in Zurich, Switzerland, which was decommissioned at the end of last year, has been reactivated and a quarantine and isolation ward for imprisoned Covid 19 patients has been established there. Generally, the number of prisoners was reduced in order to create as many single cells as possible. For this purpose, alternative custodial penalties were imposed or detention was postponed. Furthermore, hygiene standards have been improved so that inmates can now shower once a day.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services
institution_status: This service provided by the government is provided with conditions attached

description: In Switzerland on February 25, 2020, the Canton of St. Gallen announced that even though no events need to be cancelled, organizers are asked to list all participants and their contact details, especially if international participants are present. For international events with guests from risk areas (according to the FOPH), the specific situation is assessed individually by the cantonal medical office.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On February 28, the government of Schwyz announced public and private events may take place if there are less than 1000 people. This will be valid until at least March 15, 2020.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: In Switzerland the canton of Aargau decided that from the 28th of February to the 15th of March events with 150 to 999 people will have to file a request that has to be authorized by the Kantonsärztliche Dienst (KAD) (cantonal office of health) of the canton of Aargau.
enforcer: Provincial/State Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description:
On February 28th, 2020 the Federal Council of Switzerland bans public and private events in Switzerland at which more than 1000 people would gather. This ban on events comes into effect immediately and will last until at least March 15.The cantons are responsible for enforcing the ban.
In the case of public or private events at which fewer than 1000 people would gather, event organisers must carry out a risk assessment in conjunction with the competent cantonal authorities to decide whether or not the event can be held.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Provincial/State Government,Municipal Government,Police

description: on February 28, 2020 Swiss Canton Basel Stadt demanding  a permission for gathering between 200 and 1000 participants by the cantonal Department of Health

On February 28, 2020 Swiss Canton Uri announced that according to the federal ban on events with more than 1000 persons and the requirement of an cantonal risk assessment for smaller events, the cantonal special staff Corona ( "Sonderstab Corona") carried out a basic assessment for events in Uri:
Outdoor events, normal operation in restaurants, public transport, family events or events with participants knowing each other will not be restricted. All other events must be subjected to a risk assessment by the cantonal special staff corona.
type_sub_cat: Other mass gatherings not specified above restricted
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description:
On February 28th, 2020 the authorities of Swiss canton of Schaffhausen announced that events with less then 1000 persons are still allowed.
This does not apply to events with official participants from affected areas (definition FOPH, status March 4, 2020: China, Iran, South Korea, Singapore, and in Italy Lombardy, Piedmont and Veneto).
Events with more than 1000 participants are banned by the Federal Government.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: Switzerland, Geneva -- A ban on mass gatherings over 1000 people is immediately in effect from 28 February 2020 until at least 15 March 2020. For events of less than 1000 people, the organizers must, in collaboration with the cantonal authority, assess the risks to determine whether or not they can organize the event.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
On February 28, 2020 in Switzerland the government council of Canton Basel - Landschaft informed  that all events with less than 200 participants can take place. Starting Feb. 28 till March 15 for larger events with 200 to 999 participants, a decision is made in consultation between the organizer and the cantonal authorities ( the Cantonal Crisis Staff KKS ) on the basis of a risk assessment. The following criteria are decisive: 
1. proximity of contact (distance), 2. hygiene measures on site, 3. limitation of the number of participants, 4. traceability of participants and 5. composition of the audience with regard to risk groups.
A new hotline for event organizers is set up.
Event organizing without permittance can be fined.
Events with more than 1000 persons are banned by federal ordinance.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description:
On February 28, 2020 in Switzerland the Canton Jura announced 
that in the specific case of major Jura sports events - but hosting less than 1000 people -, an authorization by the Cantonal Sports Office is required.

Compared to the announcement of the Federal Council banning all mass gathering over 1000 persons the same day.

description: In Switzerland on February 28, 2020, the Canton Zug announces that with immediate effect all events with more than 200 and a maximum of 999 participants have to be registered. According to an initial risk assessment, they are allowed until March 2, 2020. The known guidelines regarding hygiene must be implemented.

description: In Switzerland on February 28, 2020, the canton Glarus implements the federal limit of 1000 persons to participate in events. Such mass gatherings are only allowed, when no one is tested positive on the corona virus and a risk assesment took place prior. Therefore, the "Sternmarsch", "Fasnachtsumzug and "Nachtumzug" in Ennenda were canceled.

description: On February 28, 2020, the Department of Health of the canton Saint Gallen announces that events up to 1000 people do not require a prior approval process.  However, events can only take place if less than 1000 people take part (federal restriction) and no people from risk countries/regions according to the Swiss federal government attend it.

description: On February 28th the Canton of Lucerne, Switzerland bans events with foreign participation from crisis areas. All other events have to be announced to the cantonal authorities and will undergo a risk assessment.
type_sub_cat: Cancellation of a recreational or commercial event

description:
On February 28, 2020 the Swiss Canton Solothurn announced that according to the federal ban on public or private events that are attended by more than 1,000 people that in Solothurn a restrictive risk assessment is carried out for events with 100 to 999 participants.
Criteria such as:
    Provide clear information to participants and employees about measures to reduce the risk of transmission (general hygiene measures, coronavirus information for travelers returning, etc.)
    Avoid participation of sick people
    Avoid participation by anyone who has been in an affected area in the past 14 days
    Ensure traceability of participants
    Composition of the audience with regard to risk groups
As a matter of principle, the special staff recommends avoiding events of this size. In any case, the organizer is obliged to consult with the canton for an implementation. A risk assessment is carried out via the hotline (0800 112 117).
 In the case of events with up to 100 people taking part, the organizers are responsible for deciding on the implementation.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On February 28, 2020, the Canton of Bern, Switzerland implements the federal restrictions of mass gatherings with immediate effect. It was decided that events with less than 1000 participants are only allowed, if organizers prove that no participants have traveled from Covid-19-affected regions in the preceding 14 days. Therefore, it must be ensured that identity of all participants is known. In addition, organizers must work with the responsible cantonal authority to make a risk assessment as to whether or not they can hold the event. A hotline will be set up for questions in this regard.

Swiss canton Zurich implements the national prohibition of mass gatherings; not more than 1000 people may meet. All events below that mass may take place without any special permission from March 4.

description: Swiss canton Zurich recommends all members of risk groups to stay away from any event on March 4. These are: People over 65, with high blood pressure, diabetes, heart- circuit problems, chronic respiratory diseases, illnesses or therapies weakening the immune system, cancer.

description: On March 4th, the Canton of Luzern, Switzerland declares that all events with less than 1000 participants have to be recorded via an online form

On March 4, 2020 in Switzerland Canton of Neuchâtel the Council of State required a risk assessment by the organizers of private or public events hosting less than 500 people. An evaluation questionnaire will be put online.This is designed as a decision aid (cancellation or maintenance) and allows an event to be assessed on the basis of several criteria:
- the importance of the event
- the ability of the organizers to identify the participants 
- the confinement of the place where the event happens (outdoors, indoors...)
- the type of activities planned

Moreover, the State council said that event organizers should:
- collect personal contact information of all participants to the event (if possible) and make this census available to public authorities if need be
- inform all participants about the collection of their personal information
- during the event, remind the protective measures that should be adopted (in accordance with the campaign of the Federal Office of Public Safety)
On March 5, the Swiss canton of Schwyz announced a ban on external events in elderly care homes; internal events should be avoided, as well.
type_sub_cat: Other mass gatherings not specified above restricted

description: In Switzerland on March 5, 2020, the Canton of Bern clarified its implementation of the federal restrictions of mass gathering further. With immediate effect, the collection of personal data of the visitors as well as the assurance of non-participation of persons who have stayed in COVID-19-affected regions is no longer necessary. For events with under 150 participants no measures need to be taken. Organizers of events with 150 - 1000 participants still must work with the responsible cantonal authority to make a risk assessment and assure compliance with guidlines of hygiene and social distancing.

description: On March 5, 2020 the Swiss Canton Saint Gallen announces that all events with over 150 and under 1000 participants have to fill out an online formular with informations regarding number of participants, form of the event and the venue. The cantonal doctor office (Kantonsamtsarzt) then decides whether the event can be held or prohibited.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description:
On March 5, 2020 the Health Department of the Swiss Canton Saint Gallen announces that all events and mass gatherings with less than 150 participants from now on have to follow these rules:
-Place appropriate notices at the entrances to your event and also draw attention to the hygiene measures.
-At the entrance check, use a simple list to ask the participants whether the participants have been in an affected area according to the BAG in the last 14 days
-At the entrance check, ask the participants whether they have symptoms such as fever, cough and difficulty breathing. If so, they should go back home.
-It is recommended that particularly vulnerable people do not participate. These include people over the age of 65 and people with serious illnesses such as diabetes, cardiovascular diseases, chronic respiratory diseases or diseases and therapies that weaken the immune system.
-Close contact such as dancing should be avoided at events.
-If possible, adjust the spatial conditions. Also check the shift to the outside
-If possible, make your guests aware of these recommendations in advance by e-mail. Affected participants should stay at home. Guests with symptoms such as fever, cough, and difficulty breathing should also stay at home.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On March 5, 2020, the Swiss Canton of Grisons announced new, more concrete measures regarding mass gatherings. All events with under 1000 participants have to undergo a risk assessment by the cantonal administration. However, there are exceptions for indoor and outdoor events specified.

description:
On February 28, 2020 in Switzerland the Canton Jura announced 
that in the specific case of major Jura sports events - but hosting less than 1000 people -, an authorization by the Cantonal Sports Office is required.

Compared to the announcement of the Federal Council banning all mass gathering over 1000 persons the same day. UPDATE: On March 5, 2020 the Swiss canton of Jura announced new measures for the organization of events with less than 1,000 people effective immediately.

description: On February 28, 2020, the Canton of Bern, Switzerland implements the federal restrictions of mass gatherings. It was decided that events with less than 1000 participants are only allowed, if organizers prove that no participants have traveled from Covid-19-affected regions in the preceding 14 days. Therefore, it must be ensured that identity of all participants is known. In addition, organizers must work with the responsible cantonal authority to make a risk assessment as to whether or not they can hold the event. A hotline will be set up for questions in this regard. UPDATE: This policy ends on March 5, 2020, because that day the Swiss Canton of Bern released new and more concrete guidelines regarding mass gatherings with less than 1000 participants.
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Provincial/State Government,Police,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description: On February 28, 2020 the Swiss Canton of Grisons implemented the federal limit of 1000 persons participating in events. In addition, in Grisons all public or private events of supraregional character or with international participation are prohibited. Regional events without international participation have to undergo a risk assessment by the cantonal authorities. UPDATE: On March 5, 2020, Grisons updated its measures regarding events with less than 1000 participants with immediate effect and implemented more stringent guidelines. However, events of supraregional character or with international participation are not generally prohibited anymore.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: The Swiss federal government announced that events with more then 1000 persons are prohibited. The authorities of the canton Schaffhausen said as a reaction to this federal policy that events with less then 1000 persons are still allowed on February 28th 2020. UPDATE: On March 6,2020 the canton of Schaffhausen has specified the rules for events with fewer than 1,000 participants. Following the criteria developed by the Federal Office of Public Health and the Conference of Health Directors from Monday, March 9, 2020. Events with 150 to 1,000 participants can still be held in the canton of Schaffhausen if the risk is weighed up and the framework conditions  by the FOPH are observed: Persons at risk should be advised not to take part, information about protective measures, people who are sick or who feel sick should be asked not to attend or leave the event

description: on march 11, 2020 Swiss Canton Ticino is limiting mass gatherings and events to 50 persons after march 12.

On March 13, 2020 in Switzerland the Government of Canton Valais prohibited all public or private events involving more than 50 people starting March 13.
Sporting and cultural activities and group events, both professional and amateur athletes, of every type and category, regardless of the number of people present were prohibited.
It was recommend to authorities, companies and others to refrain from all activities, events and meetings in which fewer than 50 people take part.
The health ministry on Appenzell-Ausserrhoden (Switzerland recommends, not to attend any event on March 13.

description: On March 13th, the Jura canton in Switzerland announced that all gatherings above 100 people were forbidden until April 4th. For restaurants, bars and clubs, the limit was set to 50.
