description:
At its meeting on March 13, 2020, the Swiss Federal Council decided on further measures: With immediate effect and until April 30, the council bans all public or private events with more than 100 people. The limit of 100 persons also applies to leisure and entertainment facilities. Cantonal authorities can approve exceptions for reasons of public interest. Events and gatherings with less than 100 participants can take place provided that measures are taken
a. to exclude people who are sick or who feel sick 
b. to protect persons belonging to a risk group
c. measures to inform those present about protective measures such as hand hygiene, keeping their distance or coughing and runny nose hygiene
d. Adaptation of the spatial conditions so that the hygiene rules can be adhered to."
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Provincial/State Government,Municipal Government,Police

description:
On March 13, 2020 Swiss Canton Geneva has announced that the decree of the Council of State of March 11, 2020 relating to mass gatherings on the territory of the Republic and canton of Geneva is repealed with immediate effect.
Noting that  Ordinance 2 COVID-19 decreed by the federal council on March 13 provides for more restrictive measures than those decreed by the Council of State of the Republic and canton of Geneva. UPDATE: The ban on events with more than 100 participants ends March 13,2020 as the federal Government decrees a stricter ban on mass gatherings.

description:
On February 28th, 2020 the Federal Council of Switzerland bans public and private events in Switzerland at which more than 1000 people would gather. This ban on events comes into effect immediately and will last until at least March 15.The cantons are responsible for enforcing the ban.
In the case of public or private events at which fewer than 1000 people would gather, event organisers must carry out a risk assessment in conjunction with the competent cantonal authorities to decide whether or not the event can be held.
This policy was abrogated already on March 13. UPDATE: The ban on large scale events was scheduled to last till March 15 but was abrogated on March 13, when a new ordinance was issued banning gatherings with more than 100 participants.

description:
On February 28, 2020 in Switzerland the government council of Canton Basel - Landschaft informed  that all events with less than 200 participants can take place. Starting Feb. 28 till March 15 for larger events with 200 to 999 participants, a decision is made in consultation between the organizer and the cantonal authorities ( the Cantonal Crisis Staff KKS ) on the basis of a risk assessment. The following criteria are decisive: 
1. proximity of contact (distance), 2. hygiene measures on site, 3. limitation of the number of participants, 4. traceability of participants and 5. composition of the audience with regard to risk groups.
A new hotline for event organizers is set up.
Event organizing without permittance can be fined.
Events with more than 1000 persons are banned by federal ordinance. UPDATE: This policy ended when it got overruled by a federal ordinance banning all gathering with more than 100 persons starting March 13, 2020, 3.30 pm.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description:
On March 5th, 2020 the Jura canton in Switzerland announced a set of conditions for mass gatherings of 150 to 999 people:
   
   The gathering must be registered at least 48 hours in advance to the Service of Public Health ("Service de la santé publique") via the email address manifestations@jura.ch by using a form available on www.jura.ch/coronavirus;
   
  The "self-declaration" form available on www.jura.ch/coronavirus needs to be adequately filled in by the organizers. By filling it, the organizers pledge to: display, in a very clear manner, the sanitary, collective and individual measures recommended by the Federal Office of Public Health ("Office fédéral de la santé publique"); to warn vulnerable populations against attending the event (people aged over 65 and in particular, people with the chronic illnesses stated in the circular); to refuse access to the event to anyone who is ill or feels ill and to order these individuals to leave the gathering.

 UPDATE: On March 13th, 2020 the Jura canton in Switzerland announced that all gatherings above 100 people were forbidden starting the same day. This is in line with the federal ban on events above 100 persons as of March 13.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On March 4, 2020, the Canton of Luzern, Switzerland declares that all events with less than 1000 participants have to be recorded via an online form. UPDATE: This policy ends on March 13, 2020, because the Swiss Federal Council decided that day to ban all events with more than 100 people until the end of April.

On February 28, 2020 the Swiss Canton Solothurn announced that according to the federal ban on public or private events that are attended by more than 1,000 people that in Solothurn a restrictive risk assessment is carried out for events with 100 to 999 participants.
Criteria such as:
    Provide clear information to participants and employees about measures to reduce the risk of transmission (general hygiene measures, coronavirus information for travelers returning, etc.)
    Avoid participation of sick people
    Avoid participation by anyone who has been in an affected area in the past 14 days
    Ensure traceability of participants
    Composition of the audience with regard to risk groups
As a matter of principle, the special staff recommends avoiding events of this size. In any case, the organizer is obliged to consult with the canton for an implementation. A risk assessment is carried out via the hotline (0800 112 117).
 In the case of events with up to 100 people taking part, the organizers are responsible for deciding on the implementation.

 UPDATE: This policy ends on March 13, 2020, because the Swiss Federal Council decided that day to ban all events with more than 100 people until the end of April.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

With immediate effect, the collection of personal data of the visitors as well as the assurance of non-participation of persons who have stayed in COVID-19-affected regions is no longer necessary. description:
On March 5, 2020 the Health Department of the Swiss Canton Saint Gallen announces that all events and mass gatherings with less than 150 participants from now on have to follow these rules:
-Place appropriate notices at the entrances to your event and also draw attention to the hygiene measures.
-At the entrance check, use a simple list to ask the participants whether the participants have been in an affected area according to the BAG in the last 14 days
-At the entrance check, ask the participants whether they have symptoms such as fever, cough and difficulty breathing. If so, they should go back home.
-It is recommended that particularly vulnerable people do not participate. These include people over the age of 65 and people with serious illnesses such as diabetes, cardiovascular diseases, chronic respiratory diseases or diseases and therapies that weaken the immune system.
-Close contact such as dancing should be avoided at events.
-If possible, adjust the spatial conditions. Also check the shift to the outside
-If possible, make your guests aware of these recommendations in advance by e-mail. Affected participants should stay at home. Guests with symptoms such as fever, cough, and difficulty breathing should also stay at home. UPDATE: This policy ends on March 13, 2020, because the Swiss Federal Council decided that day to ban all events with more than 100 people until the end of April.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

UPDATE: This policy ends on March 13, 2020, because the Swiss Federal Council decided that day to ban all events with more than 100 participants.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description:
On March 4, 2020 in Switzerland Canton of Neuchatel the Council of State required a risk assessment by the organizers of private or public events hosting less than 500 people. 
An evaluation questionnare will be put online.This is designed as a decision aid (cancellation or maintenance) and allows an event to be assessed on the basis of several criteria:
        the importance of the event
        the ability of the organizers to identify the participants 
        the confinement of the premises
        the type of activities planned
This policy was ended on March 15 by another cantonal policy banning all mass gatherings (in a confined or outdoor space), except necessary meetings of maximum 20 people. UPDATE: The original policy restricted mass gatherings by requiring a risk assessment for events bringing together less than 500 people in a confined space. On March 15, the Canton banned all mass gatherings (in a confined or outdoor space), except necessary meetings of less than 20 people, which ended the original policy.

The Swiss Canton of Fribourg announced a restriction of private and public gatherings of 50 or more people from March 16 to April 30, 2020, in order to prevent the spread of the coronavirus. Gatherings of less than 50 people are obliged to follow the hygiene recommendations of the Federal Health Agency. Public transport is exempt from this regulation and exceptions can be granted for events of public interest (e.g. gatherings to exercise political rights) which require the prior submission of a preventive concept.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description:
On March 15, 2020 in Switzerland the government council of Canton Basel Landschaft announced that starting March 16 until April 30 all public, private and religious events as well as events or gatherings with more than 50 persons are prohibited.                                                                                 
The cantonal government may exceptionally permit events with more than 50 persons if overriding public interests so require( for the exercise of political rights). Such applications must be submitted to the cantonal crisis staff (KKS) with a protection concept concerning compliance with the rules of the FOPH.
All activities of clubs and similar organizations such as sports events, training sessions, rehearsals, etc. are prohibited.
Non- compliance can be fined.

a. to exclude people who are sick or who feel sick

c. measures to inform those present about protective measures such as hand hygiene, keeping their distance or coughing and runny nose hygiene
d. Adaptation of the spatial conditions so that the hygiene rules can be adhered to.
This policy ended prematurely on March 16. UPDATE: The ban on gatherings of over 100 people was set to last till April 30. This policy ended prematurely as of March 16, when all events were prohibited.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Provincial/State Government,Municipal Government,Police

description: The health ministry on Appenzell-Ausserrhoden (Switzerland recommends, not to attend any event on March 13, 2020. UPDATE: This policy ended when it the federal council banned all events starting March 17, 2020 (March 16, midnight).
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description:
On March 13, 2020 in Switzerland the Government of Canton Valais prohibited all public or private events involving more than 50 people starting March 13.
Sporting and cultural activities and group events, both professional and amateur athletes, of every type and category, regardless of the number of people present were prohibited.
It was recommend to authorities, companies and others to refrain from all activities, events and meetings in which fewer than 50 people take part.
 UPDATE: On March 16, 2020 this policy ended prematurely when the State Council of Canton Valais prohibited all events and gatherings starting March 16, 6.30 pm.

On March 15, 2020 in Switzerland the government council of Canton Basel Landschaft announced that starting March 16 until April 30 all public, private and religious events as well as events or gatherings with more than 50 persons are prohibited.                                                                                 
The cantonal government may exceptionally permit events with more than 50 persons if overriding public interests so require( for the exercise of political rights). Such applications must be submitted to the cantonal crisis staff (KKS) with a protection concept concerning compliance with the rules of the FOPH.
All activities of clubs and similar organizations such as sports events, training sessions, rehearsals, etc. are prohibited.
Non- compliance can be fined. UPDATE: On March 16, 2020 this policy ended when it got overruled by the federal policy banning all events starting March 16 midnight.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries
compliance: Mandatory with Fines,Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)
enforcer: Provincial/State Government,Police,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description:
On March 15, 2020 in Switzerland the Government of Canton Jura bans all public, private or religious events of more than 50 people, inside and outside as of March 16 until it is lifted. Gatherings of more than 50 people can exceptionally be authorized if higher public interests require it.
The population shall be made aware of the penal consequences of non-observance of this decision, which can go up to a fine of 10'000 CHF. UPDATE: On March 16, 2020 the Swiss Federal Council announced that as of midnight the same day all public and private events are prohibited. Due to the declared extraordinary situation this overrules the cantonal policy.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries
compliance: Mandatory with Fines,Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)

description: In Switzerland, the Canton of Zug allows ice hockey games in the Bossard Arena to continue without spectators on February 28th 2020. UPDATE: On March 16, 2020 taking effect on March 17, the Federal Council of Switzerland declares an ‘extraordinary situation’ and introduces more stringent measures. Therefore, public sports events are prohibited. This overrules the decision of Canton of Zug made earlier.
type_sub_cat: Event(s) allowed to occur but no audience is allowed

description: On March 5, the Swiss canton of Schwyz announced a ban on external events in elderly care homes; internal events should be avoided, as well. UPDATE: The cantonal government of Schwyz issues a general ban on visits to nursing homes starting on March 16, 2020 and therefore forbids all kinds of mass gatherings.
type_sub_cat: Other mass gatherings not specified above restricted
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On March 13, 2020, the Swiss Canton of Grisons strengthens its measures regarding mass gatherings and prohibits all events with more than 50 persons from March 14 to at least April 30. This includes religious events. The responsible cantonal authority may exceptionally permit events if overriding public interests require this, for example events regarding political rights. UPDATE: This policy ends on March 16, 2020. The Canton of Grisons implements the Swiss Federal Council decision to ban all events with immediate effect.

On 3rd of March, Switzerland, the Canton of Zürich recommends to cancel events that implicate body contact between a larger number of people UPDATE: This policy ends on March 17, as the Swiss Federal Council prohibits all events.

The Canton Zurich (Switzerland) recommends not to hold any event with external visitors in care facilities and nursing homes on March 3. UPDATE: This policy ends on March 17, as the Swiss Federal Council prohibits all events.

description: Swiss canton Zurich recommends all members of risk groups to stay away from any event on March 4. These are: People over 65, with high blood pressure, diabetes, heart- circuit problems, chronic respiratory diseases, illnesses or therapies weakening the immune system, cancer. UPDATE: This policy ends on March 17, as the Swiss Federal Council prohibits all events.

description: The Swiss Canton of Fribourg announced a restriction of private and public gatherings of 50 or more people from March 16, 2020, in order to prevent the spread of the coronavirus. Gatherings of less than 50 people are obliged to follow the hygiene recommendations of the Federal Health Agency. Public transport is exempt from this regulation. UPDATE: This policy already ends on March 17, 2020, because the Swiss Federal Council decided to ban all events on March 16.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On 15th March 2020, the Swiss Canton of Neuchâtel prohibited all public or private mass gatherings (in a confined or outdoor space), except for necessary meetings bringing together less than 20 people, until 30th April 2020. On 16th March 2020, the Swiss Federal Council issued an order (effective 17th March 2020) that took over all cantonal measures, thus ending this policy earlier than expected. UPDATE: The original ban on mass gatherings was set to last until 30th April 2020, but the Swiss Federal Council issued an order on 16th March 2020 (effective 17th March 2020) that took over cantonal measures, thus ending the original policy.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description:
On March 16, 2020 in Switzerland Canton Jura announced that the parliamentary Session on March 25, 2020 is canceled and the objects which were to be treated there referred to a subsequent session. The committee sessions were also canceled until further notice. Videoconferences will be put in place.
Municipal assemblies, meetings of general councils or city councils were suspended.

On 18th March 2020, as part of the restrictions on mass gatherings, the Swiss Canton of Neuchâtel decided to cancel the "Semaine neuchâteloise d'actions contre le racisme"("Neuchâtel week for actions against racism"), which was supposed to take place from 16th March to 5th April.

description: On March 21, Switzerland,  Ticino prohibits all organized or spontaneous gatherings with more than five people. Violations of the prohibitions can be punished with a disciplinary fine of CHF 100.-

On March 20, 2020 the Swiss Federal Council banned gathering of more than five people in public as of March 21st. Social distancing is compulsory for all persons in public. Non-compliance can be fined.
As before (start March 17, 2020) all public or private events, including parties, sports events, club activities, markets, religious services, political demonstrations and general assemblies remain forbidden. Event organizising can be punished.
Exempted are private gathering in small groups at home ( but not recommended), funerals in close family circle, playing children (in  groups of five) and business meetings which should be limited to 1 person per 4 qm in closed rooms.
 UPDATE: The ban on all public and private events ( March 16) still allowed private gathering in small groups. The Swiss federal council will now ban any gathering of more than five people in public spaces as of March 21st (announced March 20th), every persons has to socially distance ( 2m), non-compliance can be fined.
type_sub_cat: Attendance at religious services restricted (e.g. mosque/church closings)

description:
Switzerland, Geneva--"The cantonal police, with the support of the Civil Protection (PCi), proceeded this morning, Saturday March 28, to a cordon of the lakeside surroundings in order to prohibit the parking of private vehicles. The objective of this measure is to severely restrict the gatherings of people in the same place as part of the fight against the spread of the COVID-19 virus."

Original: La police cantonale, avec l'appui de la Protection civile (PCi), a procédé ce matin, samedi 28 mars, à un bouclage des abords lacustres afin d'interdire le stationnement des véhicules privés. L'objectif de cette mesure est de restreindre fortement les rassemblements de personnes sur un même lieu dans le cadre de la lutte contre la propagation du virus COVID-19.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

On March 16, 2020 in Switzerland the Federal Council banned all public or private events, including parties, sports events, political demonstrations and General assemblies as of March 17.
Exempted are private gathering in small groups ( in public spaces and at home), playing children (recommended group size 5) and business meetings which should be limited to 1 person per 4qm in closed rooms. This was scheduled to end April 19th.
On April 8th the Federal Council decided to extend the ban on events and gatherings by one week till April 26th. UPDATE: The ban on events and gathering in groups of more than five persons was set to last till April 19, it has been extended till April 26.

description:
On 22nd April 2020, the state council of the Swiss Canton of Neuchâtel decided to ban all mass gatherings bringing together several hundreds of people up until 21st June 2020 at the earliest. 

NB: this policy echoes the "deconfinement plan" released by the Swiss Federal Council on 16th April 2020, which reaffirms the ban on mass gatherings but doesn't give any end date to this ban. The Neuchâtel state council specified in their news release that they were giving the date of 21st June 2020 to clarify the situation and give more visibility to event organizers.
type_sub_cat: Other mass gatherings not specified above restricted
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On 24th April 2020, the Swiss Canton of Neuchâtel decided to postpone to 2021 the cross-cultural festival NeuchàToi, which was supposed to occur from 30th August to 30th October 2020. A new date hasn't been set yet for this annually recurring event which should have celebrated its 5th year in 2020.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On April 24, 2020 in Switzerland Canton Jura announced that the holding of municipal assemblies, meetings of general councils or city councils remain suspended. These meetings and sessions may resume from May 25, 2020. UPDATE: Parliamentary sessions and municipal assemblies were canceled till further notice, now they can resume starting May 25.

On April 16, 2020 at its meeting the Swiss Federal Council decided the next steps for gradually easing measures against coronavirus after April 27. The restriction whereby funerals may only be attended by close family will also be lifted as of April 27th, provided a protection concept complying to the guidelines of the Federal Office of Health.
As before (start March 17, 2020) and till May 10th all public or private events, including parties, sports events, club activities, markets, religious services, political demonstrations and general assemblies remain forbidden. Event organizising can be punished. Gathering of more than five people in public is still banned (start March 21st). Social distancing is compulsory for all persons in public. Non-compliance can be fined.
Exempted are private gathering in small groups at home ( but not recommended), playing children (in groups of five) and business meetings which should be limited to 1 person per 4 qm in closed rooms, funerals. UPDATE: The ban on gathering over five persons and all public and private events was set to last till April 26th, it has been extended till May 10th. But the restrictions on funerals have been relaxed, from funerals in close family circle to funerals in larger family circle.
type_sub_cat: Attendance at religious services restricted (e.g. mosque/church closings)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
On April 29, 2020, the Swiss Federal Council decided at its meeting on the next steps to relax the measures against the coronavirus. From May 11th, sports clubs can resume training for amateur athletes in groups of five and without physical contact and with more exceptions for competitive athletes (permanent teams). Markets can take place.
As before (start March 17, 2020) and till presumably June 7 th all public or private events, including parties, sports events, other club activities, religious services, political demonstrations and general assemblies remain forbidden. Event organizising can be punished. Gathering of more than five people in public is still banned (start March 21st). Social distancing is compulsory for all persons in public. Non-compliance can be fined. 
Exempted are private gathering in small groups at home, playing children at school play-grounds and business meetings (limited to 1 person per 4 qm), funerals (in a family-closed friends-circle), training of competitive athletes in permanent teams, markets. UPDATE: The ban on gathering over five persons and on all public and private events was set to last till May 10th, it has been extended till June 7th. But more exemptions are allowed.

description:
On February 28, 2020 Swiss Canton Ticino is requiring a notification for events with less than 1000 participants and international participation
( in addition to the federal ban on events with more than 1000 participants). All carnival activities are forbidden. UPDATE: The original measure for the restriction on mass gathering was introduced on February 28 with the obligation of permission for more than 1.000 people. As of March 7 gatherings of more than 150 people were forbidden and as of March 12 gatherings of more than 50 people. On March 21 further restrict gathering to a maximum of 5 people. As of May 30 gatherings of up to 30 people are allowed and on June 6 manifestations with up to 300 participants.

On May 20, 2020 the Swiss Federal Council announced  that faith communities should be able to resume their common religious life. From the 28th of May 2020, all services and celebrations of all faiths will once again be permitted. The religious communities have one week to work out protection concepts and to ensure the tracing of possible chains of infection. A framework protection concept has been drawn up by the Federal Office of Public Health (FOPH). UPDATE: The ban on gathering over five persons and on all public and private events was set to last till June 7th. But religious services were allowed to resume prematurely as of May 28th ( announced May 20) without limit in number of participants.
type_sub_cat: Attendance at religious services restricted (e.g. mosque/church closings)

On May 27, 2020, the Swiss Federal Council decided at its meeting on further easing the measures put in place to fight the new coronavirus starting May 30. 
Till and including May 29 gathering of more than five people in public is  banned (start March 21st). Social distancing is compulsory for all persons in public. Non-compliance can be fined. 
As before (start March 17, 2020) and till presumably June 7 th all public or private events, including parties, sports events, club activities, political demonstrations and general assemblies remain forbidden. Event organizising can be punished.

description:
On May 27th, 2020 in Switzerland the Federal Council decided: The ban on gatherings in public, in particular in public spaces, promenades and parks is to be eased. As of 30 May, the upper limit will be increased from 5 to 30 people.
Gathering in groups over 30 persons can be fined, not adhering to social distancing rules is no longer to be fined. Nevertheless social distancing remains highly recommended. Exempted are school children at school playgrounds.

description: The Swiss Canton Ticino announces that 30 people are allowed to gather as of May 30, instead of only 5. UPDATE: The limit of people gathering of max 5 people from March 2, is eased to max 30 as of May 30.

In Fribourg, Switzerland on May 19, 2020, the cantonal leadership body (KFO) decided to use its small scope to grant exceptions to the federal limit of 5 persons gathering. From now on, association boards are allowed to meet again even if more than 5 people attend. However, those present must comply to the rules of hygiene and conduct. The number of people attending the meeting must be limited and the guideline of 4 m2 per person in the meeting room must be guaranteed, as well as the physical distance of 2 m between people during the meeting. UPDATE: On May 30, 2020, this policy becomes obsolet, because the Swiss Federal Council decided on May 27 to allow gatherings of 30 persons.
type_sub_cat: Other mass gatherings not specified above restricted
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Provincial/State Government,Police,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description:
On May 27, 2020 the Swiss Federal Council decided that 
from June 6th, private and public events with up to 300 people are to be allowed.This includes family events, fairs, concerts, club activities, sports events/competitions, theatre performances and film screenings, general assemblies,as well as political and civil society demonstrations.
On condition that all events have appropriate sets of precautionary measures in place. Hygiene and social distancing rules must still be observed. If it is not possible to respect social distancing rules, contact tracing must be assured, by means of attendance lists, for example. 
Summer holiday camps for children and young people will be allowed to go ahead from 6 June as long as appropriate sets of precautionary measures are in place. Children and young people should remain in the same groups wherever possible. The upper limit for camps is 300 people and organisers must keep an attendance list.
Cantons can allow exemptions for important reasons. Non-public events ( family events, club activities where people know each other) with less than 30 persons only have to ensure contact tracing.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
compliance: Mandatory with Legal Penalties (Jail Time),Mandatory with Fines,Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Provincial/State Government,Municipal Government,Police

description:
On June 4th, 2020 in Switzerland the canton of Jura announced that starting June 6th in order to ensure traceability, events and gatherings of 30 to 300 people will have to be announced in advance to the cantonal authorities.Their organizers will also have to provide protection plans in compliance with the federal standards in force. Announcements must be made no later than 5 days before the event is held. A form is available at www.jura.ch/coronavirus.
This policy ended on October 9th, when new regulations on events came in force.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Provincial/State Government,Municipal Government

description:
On 11th June 2020, the Swiss canton of Neuchâtel specified the details of the mandatory protection plan for all public mass gatherings between 30 and 300 people. The organizer of the event will have to submit an application to the Department of Consumption and Veterinary Affairs specifying the name of the person in charge of the Covid safety measures. If the 2 meters social distancing cannot be respected, contact tracing has to be implemented by listing the names and phone numbers of participants; this data shall be stored for 14 days and made available to the government if need be.

NB: this policy follows on from the federal government's announcement on 6th June 2020 that mass gatherings up to 300 people could be organized in Switzerland, as long as they have a protection plan.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries
enforcer: Provincial/State Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On 11th June 2020, the Swiss canton of Neuchâtel announced that private mass gatherings of up to 300 people (in compliance with the 6th June 2020 federal policy allowing mass gatherings up to 300 people) can be organized without a protection plan (i.e. a document to be submitted to the canton), but hygiene and social distancing measures have to be respected. If they can't be respected, contact tracing has to be implemented by collecting the personal data (names, phone numbers) of participants.

description: On July 3, the Swiss Canton Ticino limits the maximal number of people gathering back to 30 and the number of people in bars, night clubs, discotheques to 100 people maximum. This policy is implemented immediately until July 19. UPDATE: As of June 22 the decision from the Federal Government allowed gatherings of more than 30 people and manifestations with max 1.000 participants if distances could be guaranteed. With raising cases, the Swiss Canton Ticino announced on July 3, that the number of people gathering will be again limited to 30 persons and max 100 in night bars and clubs, to be implemented immediately until July 19.

On July 8th, the government of the Swiss Canton Solothurn announced that public and private events for 101 to 1000 people would have to be conducted in seperate rooms for a maximum of 100 people each. This number excludes active participants (e.g. actors, artists). Furthermore, event organizers would have to identify, record and verify contact data of all visitors. This policy was scheduled to take into effect on July 9th and expire on August 31st.

description:
On July 8, 2020 in Switzerland Canton Basel-Landschaft starting July 9 till August 31 requires a subdivision of public and private events with more than 100 persons at which neither the required distance can be maintained nor protective measures are taken, and therefore contact data must be collected (according to the federal  Covid-19 Ordinance special situation). A subdivision into standing or seated sectors with a maximum of 100 people must be made. In addition, outside these sectors, if there is a possibility of mixing, either the minimum distance must be maintained or a protective mask must be worn.
Events with more than 1000 persons are banned by the federal government.

target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description:
On July 8, 2020, in Swistzerland the government council of canton Basel-City announced that despite a federal limit of 300 people per sector on public and private events, it would lower this limit to 100 if social distancing and other protective measures cannot be guaranteed as of July 9 till December 31, 2020.
Non-compliance can be fined.

description: In Switzerland, on July 10, 2020, the Canton Zug adds the following measures to the federal restrictions of mass gatherings effective July 13 until August 31. Organisers of events with over 300 participants must ensure that either the required distance of 1.5m is kept or protective measures i.e. mask wearing are in place. If organisers of events with 31 to 300 participants cannot ensure that the required distance is kept or such protective measures are in place, persons in attendance have to split in sectors of a a maximum of 30 persons inside and 100 outside. Contact data must be recorded. Exempted from splitting into sectors are family events with a maximum of 100 participants.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On July 15, 2020, the Swiss canton of Lucerne announced that despite the federal limit of 300 people for public and private events, it would lower the limit to a maximum of 100 if social distancing, mask wearing, or other protective measures cannot be guaranteed. In this case, closed sectors with a maximum of 100 people need to be established.

description:
At its meeting on August 12, the Swiss Federal Council took the decision to extend the ban on large scale events with more than 1000 persons till September 30. Large-scale events will be permitted from October under strict conditions and with a permit by cantonal authorities.
This gives the cantons time to prepare the permit system and increase their contact tracing capacities, if necessary.
 UPDATE: The ban on mass gathering over 1000 persons was scheduled to end August 31st, but it has been extended to Spetember 30, 2020.

description:
On July 8, 2020 in Switzerland Canton Basel-Landschaft starting July 9 till August 31 requires a subdivision of public and private events with more than 100 persons at which neither the required distance can be maintained nor protective measures are taken, and therefore contact data must be collected (according to the federal  Covid-19 Ordinance special situation). A subdivision into standing or seated sectors with a maximum of 100 people must be made. In addition, outside these sectors, if there is a possibility of mixing, either the minimum distance must be maintained or a protective mask must be worn.
Events with more than 1000 persons are banned by the federal government. UPDATE: On August 17, 2020, the Canton of Basel-Landschaft announced the extension of this policy  until September 30. (General decree no. 4).
type_sub_cat: Other mass gatherings not specified above restricted
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

The policy is extended until September 21.

description: From August 27, 2020 until September 30 in Zurich (Switzerland) indoor events with more than 100 people are prohibited unless participants are wearing face masks or maintain the required distance. If a precautionary measures plan is implemented events with more than 100 people are still permitted within the framework of national guidelines. If the event takes place both indoors and outdoors, these protective measures must be taken if more than 300 people attend. UPDATE: The original policy was set to last until September 30, 2020, it has been extended to October 31.

description: In accordance with federal regulations decided upon on August 12, the Swiss canton of Obwalden begins to allow events with over 1000 attendees under certain conditions, if the number of infections remains low: All such events must be approved by the cantonal administration. The application for the event must be submitted at least one month in advance except for events in October, where the deadline is 10 days before the scheduled date. Organizers must outline a hygiene concept to ensure hygiene and social distancing, visitors must remain seated during the event, and the flow of people must be regulated. Furthermore, there must be a plan for the handling of suspected cases.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: In accordance with federal regulations decided upon on August 12, the Swiss canton of Nidwalden begins to allow events with over 1000 attendees under certain conditions, if the number of infections remains low and the canton has sufficient capacities for contact tracing: All such events must be approved by the cantonal administration. The application for the event must be submitted at least six weeks in advance except for events before November 8, which can be approved at shorter notice. Organizers must outline a hygiene concept to ensure hygiene and social distancing, visitors must remain seated during the event, seats must be assigned to specific individuals, and the flow of people must be regulated. Furthermore, there must be a plan for the handling of suspected cases.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On September 24, 2020, the Swiss canton of Uri issued its guidelines for the approval of mass events (over 1000 participants) based on federal guidelines, effective from October 1. Organizers must submit an application in advance and outline a hygiene concept. Visitors of an event must be seated on personalised spots, social distancing and hygiene must be ensured at all times, and there must be a procedure to handle suspected cases. Events can only be approved if the number of infections s low enough and the capacities for contact tracing at the local authorities are ensured. Permits can be revoked if any of the aforementioned conditions is no longer met.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: Following federal guidelines on the approval for the permission with over 1000 participants after October 1, the Swiss canton of Schwyz announced its guidelines for the permission of such events on September 10: Organizers must apply for permission in advance and outline a hygiene concept. Visitors must be seated during the event, and seats must be assigned to a specific individual. Furthermore, infection rates in the canton must be low enough and authorities must be able to ensure contact tracing for events to be approved.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On September 25, 2020 the Swiss Canton Grisons announces that mass gatherings (like concerts, sport events etc.) with over 1000 participants will be allowed again starting October 1, 2020. This measure was initiated after the "Bundesrat", the national parliament of Switzerland, decided on August 12, 2020, that mass gatherings with over 1000 participants should be allowed again starting October 1. The organizer of the mass gathering has to submit an application to the Cantonal health department at least 20days before the event. Also an protection concept must be submitted. At the end the the Canton has to approve or withdraw each event individually depending on the epidemiological situation.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: The goverment of the Swiss Canton Saint Gallen announced on September 18, 2020, that mass gatherings with over 1000 participants will be allowed again starting October 1, 2020.This measure was initiated after the "Bundesrat", the Swiss national parliament decided on August 20, 2020 that mass gatherings with over 1000 participants should be allowed again. This measure must be implemented by the Cantons.  The event organizer first has to submit a application with a safety concept to the state health department and the county, where the mass gathering should take place. If the epidemiological situation should get worse a permission also can be withdrawn

The announcement of a private event is made using an online form.

description: 10th September 2020, following the decision of the Federal Council of August 12, major events ( 1000+ people)will be authorized again from October 1, 2020, subject to an authorization issued by the competent cantonal service. In the Swiss Canton of Neuchâtel, each organizer must submit an authorization request at least 30 days before the planned event. A major event is defined in regards to a number of people exceeding 1000.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description:
On September 2, 2020 the Swiss Federal Council, after consultation with the cantons and associations, has defined licensing requirement for large-scale outdoor events (cultural, sports, congress, religious) with more than 1000 participants that may be held again from October 1, 2020. 
The events have to be authorised by the cantons, taking into account the local epidemiological situation and contact tracing capacity. The cantons can revoke a permit or order additional restrictions if the epidemiological development deteriorates.
The organizer must submit a risk analysis and a corresponding precautionary measures plan. Among other things, this must regulate how the flow of people is controlled, whether masks are compulsory, whether seats are to be kept free or how it is ensured that the contact details collected are correct. Social distancing ( masks or distance keeping) and hygiene rules apply. Seating is compulsory in the spectator area. At open-air events, the cantons may by way of exception permit spectators to stand in certain areas, provided these areas are divided into sectors and additional precautionary measures are planned.
Holding an event without permit or compliance to the precautionary measures plan is fined.
This does not apply to political and civil society demonstrations and to the championship games of the national professional sports leagues.This policy ends when all events with more than 50 people were prohibited starting October 29, 2020.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
On September 2, 2020 the Swiss Federal Council, after consultation with the cantons and associations, has defined licensing requirement for championship games of the national professional sports leagues (e.g. ice hockey and soccer) that may be held again with more than 1000 spectators starting October 1, 2020. 
The events have to be authorised by the cantons, taking into account the local epidemiological situation and the cantonal contact tracing capacity. The cantons can revoke a permit or order additional restrictions if the epidemiological development deteriorates.
The organizer must submit a corresponding precautionary measures plan: among others: spectators must wear masks (except children, medical reasons), spectators must be seated, seats must be allocated to the individual persons, the maximum number of seats may not exceed two thirds of the entire capacity, the flow of people must be controlled, correct contact details have to be collected. Social distancing and hygiene rules apply. No allocation of seats may be sold or given to supporters of the visiting team.The sale and the consumption of alcoholic drinks must be restricted,only seated consumption. Holding an event without permit or compliance to the precautionary measures plan is fined. This policy ends when all events with more than 50 people were prohibited starting October 29, 2020.
type_sub_cat: Other mass gatherings not specified above restricted
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:

The events have to be authorised by the cantons, taking into account the local epidemiological situation and the cantonal contact tracing capacity. The cantons can revoke a permit or order additional restrictions if the epidemiological development deteriorates.
The organizer must submit a risk analysis and a corresponding precautionary measures plan. Among other things, this must regulate how the flow of people is controlled, whether masks are compulsory, whether seats are to be kept free or how it is ensured that the contact details collected are correct. Social distancing ( masks or distance keeping) and hygiene rules apply. Seating is compulsory in the spectator area, seats must be allocated to the individual person.
Holding an event without permit or while failing to comply with the precautionary measures plan is fined. description:
On March 14, 2020 the Swiss Federal Office of Health issues guidelines for wearing masks.
chirurgical/ hygiene masks are recommended for
- health staff under certain conditions
- caregiver for particularly vulnerable persons ( e.g. staff in nursing homes)

description: On March 17, 2020 in Switzerland the Government Council of Canton Basel City restricted the use of  public parks, green spaces, squares and the banks of the Rhine. The control of the coronavirus requires everyone to keep their distance from each other, even outdoors. Everyone is urged not to stay for a long time in the recreational areas with large public traffic. Conducting picnics and barbecues is prohibited. Walking or jogging is allowed in the recreation areas. Children with their caregivers may stay in playgrounds. If everyone is considerate of these rules, the parks and public green spaces can remain open.
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart at Beaches
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: The City of Bern, Switzerland closes the Bundesterrasse and other parks effective March 20th

description: On March 20 the Swiss Federal Council announces that in order to prevent the closure of construction sites and to offer better protection to employees, employers in the construction sector and industry are required to comply with the federal recommendations on hygiene and social distancing. Therefore, employers must limit the number of people present on construction sites or in other workplaces, and prevent groups of people from gathering in break rooms and canteens. The cantons may close down individual companies or construction sites if they do not comply.

description:
On March 20, 2020:
Because people have not being fully complying with the rules on social distancing the Swiss Federal Council has decided that in public places people must keep a distance of at least two metres from each other starting March 21 till April 19. The police may impose a fine for non-compliance.

description: Valais (Switzerland) recommends all citizens on March 24 to conduct necessary outgoings at locations and times where people are as isolated as possible and distance to others is respected as well as to stay at the balkony in the sun to minimize the risk of infection. description: On April 1, 2020, the Swiss Federal Council decided to temporarily change the regulation on electronic signatures. The change provides a general way of video identification when issuing certificates, making physical signatures redundant. This way, trips and personal contacts can be avoided UPDATE: The social distancing regulations have been expanded by temporarily allowing electronic signatures and verifications for a maximum period of 6 months to avoid social contact, starting April 1st 2020.

The Swiss Federal Council has made adjustments to the asylum procedure in Switzerland which is to be coordinated across all cantons from April 1st 2020. The changes include greater physical distance in the asylum interview process (fewer individuals in the room etc) and additional accommodation for asylum applicants who are unable to leave due to COVID-19 to be made by converting military accommodation.

description:
On March 6th, 2020 at its press conference the Swiss Federal council and the Federal Office of Health released recommendations (factsheet)  for the population including the advice to keep distance .
On its website ( March 5 ) the FOPH recommends: " Keep your distance e.g. protect the elderly by keeping a save distance. Keep your distance from others in a queue. Keep your distance at meetings." UPDATE: At its meeting on April 8 the Swiss Federal Council decided to extend the measures by a week from April 20 to April 26 including the obligation of social distancing in public spaces.

description: On March 3, 2020, the cantonal government of Fribourg restricts the work of government staff. In order to reduce the risk of infection during rush hours, block hours (normally 8:30am-11:00am and 2:00pm-4:00pm) will be eliminated until further notice. A simplified procedure for home office will apply. Counter service to the public is guaranteed, but individual counter calls are limited to 10 minutes. UPDATE: From May 4, 2020 onwards, starting with the civil services administration, cantonal counter services have started to reopen under strict social distancing measures and prior registration rules. June 2, reopening of the labor service counter,. However, home office and the use of online tools is advised whenever possible.

Everyone is urged not to stay for a long time in the recreational areas with large public traffic. Conducting picnics and barbecues is prohibited. Walking or jogging is allowed in the recreation areas. Children with their caregivers may stay in playgrounds. If everyone is considerate of these rules, the parks and public green spaces can remain open. UPDATE: Starting May 30, 20202 the ban on picnics and barbecues in public spaces was lifted when the the federal limit of gathering in public spaces was eased from 5 to 30 persons.
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart at Beaches
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries
compliance: Mandatory with Fines,Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)

The control of the coronavirus requires everyone to keep their distance from each other, even outdoors. Everyone is urged not to stay for a long time in the recreational areas with large public traffic. Conducting picnics and barbecues is prohibited. Walking or jogging is allowed in the recreation areas. Children with their caregivers may stay in playgrounds. If everyone is considerate of these rules, the parks and public green spaces can remain open. UPDATE: Starting May 30, 20202 the ban on picnics and barbecues in public spaces was lifted when the the federal limit of gathering in public spaces was eased from 5 to 30 persons.

description:
On March 6th, 2020 at its press conference the Swiss Federal council and the Federal Office of Health released recommendations (factsheet)  for the population including the advice to keep distance .
On its website ( March 5 ) the FOPH recommends: " Keep your distance e.g. protect the elderly by keeping a save distance. Keep your distance from others in a queue. Keep your distance at meetings." UPDATE: The FOPH  announced on June 5th that the Federal Council has abolished (on May 30) the fine for non-compliance with the distance. (Covid 19 Ordinance 2 change Art. 7c valid from May 30 till July 5). The recommendations on distance are not applicable to people for whom compliance is inappropriate, in particular to schoolchildren, parents with their children or people who can be shown to live in the same household.
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart

description: On June 4th, the Jura canton in Switzerland announced that, following the federal announcement of May 27th, post-compulsory school (ages 15+) will be allowed to resume starting Monday, June 8th. The re-opening will incorporate hygiene measures as dictated by the Federal Office of Public Health. Social distancing (2 meters) will be put in place and hand washing hygiene is promoted.
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart at Secondary Schools (generally for children ages 10 to 18)
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On 8th June 2020, the RHNe (Neuchâtel hospital network) of the Swiss Canton of Neuchâtel announced that from 9th June 2020 on, all visitors had to wear a mask while visiting their relatives in hospital and that they had to keep a distance of at least 1 meter apart from the patients.

description:
On June 19, 2020 the Swiss Federal Council announced that there is no upper limit for the number of people able to attend a demonstration, but it will be mandatory to wear a face mask. This change concerning political and civil society demonstrations will apply from Saturday, 20 June.
Gathering of less than 30 persons are excepted from mask obligation.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Provincial/State Government,Municipal Government,Police

description: On June 19, the Federal Council of Switzerland announces that from June 22 until September 13 operators of publicly accessible establishments and businesses such as restaurants, bars, clubs and discotheques and dance venues must draw up and implement a precautionary measures plan. It must include measures relating to hygiene and social distancing. The following persons are exempted from maintaining the required distance of 1,5m: groups of pupils, families or persons of the same household. Otherwise guests have to wear a mask or other effective protective measures must be taken, such as erecting suitable barriers. In the case of seats arranged in rows or in a similar way, in particular in theatres, concert halls and cinemas, only every second seat or seats separated by an equivalent distance may be occupied. The contact details of the persons present must be recorded if it is possible that they will be unable to maintain the required distance for a period in excess of 15 minutes and other protective measures are not in place. The contact details must on request be passed on to the competent cantonal authority or organization for the purpose of identifying and notifying persons who may have been infected. If over 300 persons and a maximum of 1000 persons are present, they must be split into groups of 300 persons per sector. Violation will be punished by fines.
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart at Restaurants
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: With the start of the special situation in Switzerland as announced on June 19, 2020, the Swiss Federal Council implements preventive measures regarding employees effective June 22. It is said that employers must ensure compliance with the recommendations of the FOPH concerning hygiene and social distancing and therefore, must implement appropriate measures. If the required distance cannot be maintained, measures must be taken in accordance with the STOP principle (substitution, technical measures, organizational measures, personal protective equipment), i.e. home office, physical separation, separate teams or mask wearing.
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart at All or unspecified businesses
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: From May 12 on the Swiss canton Aargau will reopen all locations of the Museum Aargau in compliance with the federal guidlines on protection concepts. In addition to disinfectants and floor markings for the minimum distance, a limited number of visitors are allowed to enter the premises. Wherever possible, the entrances and exits as well as tours of the museum are separated by direction. Only a few areas in which the distance and hygiene rules cannot be observed remain temporarily closed. UPDATE: This policy ends on June 22, 2020, as the Swiss Federal Council has published guidelines on implementing a precautionary measures plan on June 19.
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart at Public museums/galleries
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On March 20 the Swiss Federal Council announces that in order to prevent the closure of construction sites and to offer better protection to employees, employers in the construction sector and industry are required to comply with the federal recommendations on hygiene and social distancing. Therefore, employers must limit the number of people present on construction sites or in other workplaces, and prevent groups of people from gathering in break rooms and canteens. The cantons may close down individual companies or construction sites if they do not comply. UPDATE: On June 19, 2020, the Swiss Federal Council has ended the exceptional situation in Switzerland and implements new, less stringent measures regarding employees in the construction sector and industry effective June 22.
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart at Construction
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
On March 6th, 2020 at its press conference the Swiss Federal council and the Federal Office of Health released recommendations (factsheet)  for the population including the advice to keep distance .
On its website ( March 5 ) the FOPH recommends: " Keep your distance e.g. protect the elderly by keeping a save distance. Keep your distance from others in a queue. Keep your distance at meetings." UPDATE: On June 19, 2020 in view of the low number of cases, the Swiss Federal Council is reducing the minimum distance that should be kept between two people from 2 metres to 1.5 metres starting June 22. If masks are worn or partitions are in place, the distance may be further reduced.
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart

description: The canton of Bern, Switzerland, announces on 30 June that masks will be mandatory in prisons. This includes both prisoners and prison staff. Prisoners must wear masks any time they are outside of their cells.

On June 30th, the Jura canton in Switzerland announced that, following the emergence of a few positive cases in the canton, the public (anyone above 10 years old) was advised to buy packs of 50 face masks to wear when social distancing was not possible, in preparation for a possible second wave of the pandemic. 

Note: People under the Lamal subsidy will receive those for free.

description: On 3rd July 2020, the Swiss canton of Neuchâtel issued some recommendations for resuming activities after the summer break. The canton recommended that whenever possible, employers should implement remote working during one or two weeks for employees coming back from vacation. If this is impossible, it recommends that employers implement mask wearing during the same period of time for employees coming back from vacation. These measures aim at avoiding the spread of the virus after the summer break.

These policies include a health questionnaire for visitors, mandatory masks for visitors and restrictions on visits. Visits are now limited to one or two people a day and for no longer than one hour.

At its meeting on 1 July, the SwissFederal Council has decided to make masks compulsory on public transport throughout the country from Monday, 6 July. Persons over the age of 12 will have to wear a mask in trains, trams and buses, as well as on mountain rail and cableways and on lake and river boats.
An urgent recommendation is already in place to wear a mask when travelling on public transport at peak times.

description:
The Federal Council has decided on July 1st that as of July 6th travelers in public transport must wear a face mask in all vehicles. This now also applies to aircraft as of August 12ve.
This does not apply to: a. Children before their 12th birthday; b. People who can prove that they are unable to wear face masks for special reasons, particularly medical ones.
The measure affects all scheduled and charter flights that take off or land in Switzerland, regardless of the airline.

description:
On August 5, 2020 in Switzerland the Departement of Education in Canton Basel-City anounced that after summer break ( August 10th)  the "Mittelschulen" ( upper secondary age above 15) and vocational schools are faced with the challenge of complying with the distance rules by the Federal Office of Health. Where this is not possible, masks and plexiglass solutions can be used.
Schools made extensive changes in the classrooms in order to enable teaching in full classes.This also includes the purchase of additional individual desks. In this way, a general mask requirement can be avoided during lessons. A mask requirement should only exist where the distances cannot be maintained, e.g. practical training, in training workshops, in laboratory lessons.
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description:
On August 5, 2020 in Switzerland the Departement of Education in Canton Basel-City anounced that after summer break ( August 10th)  the "Mittelschulen" ( upper secondary age above 15) and vocational schools are faced with the challenge of complying with the distance rules by the Federal Office of Health. Where this is not possible, masks and plexiglass solutions can be used.
Schools made extensive changes in the classrooms in order to enable teaching in full classes.This also includes the purchase of additional individual desks. In this way, a general mask requirement can be avoided during lessons. A mask requirement should only exist where the distances cannot be maintained, e.g. practical training, in training workshops, in laboratory lessons.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries
compliance: Mandatory (Unspecified/Implied),Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)

description: The Swiss canton of Solothurn requires the wearing of face masks at all secondary schools, including in class unless social distancing can be ensured by students staying min. 1.5m apart or being separated by a barrier. Other exceptions include sports classes and choir exercises if a distance of min. 3m can be ensured. Details will be decided at the individual school level.
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart at Secondary Schools (generally for children ages 10 to 18)
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries
enforcer: Provincial/State Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: 14th August 2020, Neuchatel, Swizterland, The start of the post-compulsory school year ( 16 years old and older) can proceed as normal as possible due to the implementation of specific health protection measures. On Monday August 17, 2020, apprentices will attend in-person and full classes. High school students will follow on Monday, August 24, 2020.
type_sub_cat: Wearing Masks inside Secondary Schools (generally for children ages 10 to 18)
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On 13th August 2020, the Swiss canton of Neuchâtel announced that students will return back to school after the summer break on 17th August 2020  in full classes. The opening of schools is subject to social distancing (1 meter at least) and hygiene measures (hand sanitizer, washing hands regularly), in compliance with the recommendations of the Federal Office of Public Health.

description: On July 3, the Swiss Canton Ticino highly recommends for people working in customer service the use of face masks or face shields UPDATE: On August 19, the Swiss Canton Ticino extends the compulsory wearing of mask or other protection devices for the staff in charge of customer service of all types of catering establishments, where a structural device in Plexiglas or equivalent is not installed. The policy is extended until September 07.
type_sub_cat: Wearing Masks in all public spaces/everywhere
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On July 3, the Swiss Canton Ticino highly recommends for people working in customer service the use of face masks or face shields UPDATE: On August 19, the Swiss Canton Ticino extends the compulsory wearing of mask or other protection devices for the staff in charge of customer service of all types of catering establishments, where a structural device in Plexiglas or equivalent is not installed. The policy is extended until September 07.

description: On 3rd July 2020, the Swiss canton of Neuchâtel strongly recommended wearing a mask in businesses and stores. The canton indicated that this recommendation could become mandatory if Covid-19 cases in Neuchâtel were to increase again. On 19th August 2020, the canton announced that mask wearing would be now mandatory in shops with a capacity of more than 10 people from 21st August 2020 on, thus ending this policy. UPDATE: The original policy was a general recommandation for mask wearing in all shops, but on 19th August 2020, the canton made mask wearing mandatory in shops with a capacity of +10 people, thus ending this policy.
type_sub_cat: Wearing Masks inside All or unspecified businesses
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On 19th August 2020, the Swiss canton of Neuchâtel announced that mask wearing would be mandatory in enclosed shops with a capacity of more than 10 people (staff included) and malls. The following businesses are exempted from this measure: shops with a floor space of maximum 80m2, places which involve sports activities, banks and post offices. This measure enters into force on 21st August 2020 and will last until 30th September 2020.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: In Switzerland on August 19, 2020, the governing council of Zug implements a mask obligation for all services where physical contact is involved or the required distance cannot be maintained effective August 22. This applies to establishments such as hairdressing salons, tattoo studios, cosmetic studios and massage salons. All persons present, i.e. both customers and employees, have to wear masks.
type_sub_cat: Wearing Masks inside Personal Grooming Businesses (e.g. hair salons)
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description:
On August 20, 2020 the Government Council of Swiss Canton Basel City decided to make wearing a mask compulsory effective Monday August 24th till December 31 for all publicly accessible indoor areas in sales outlets and shopping centers as well as for the service staff of restaurants and bars.
This does not apply to children under the age of 12 or employees protected by a plexiglass pane. First and foremost, certified or compliant masks are recommended. Scarves or other non-specific textiles are not face masks in the present sense.
Business operator can be fined for non- compliance.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

Since the safety distance can be maintained in the classrooms of upper secondary schools, lessons continue to take place without masks. First and foremost, certified or compliant masks are recommended. Scarves or other non-specific textiles are not face masks in the present sense.

description: Zurich (Switzerland) implements a mask obligation in businesses from August 27 until Septmber 30. The following persons are exempted from this requirement: children under the age of 12; persons who can prove that they are unable to wear face masks for compelling reasons, in particular medical reasons; employees, if effective protective measures, such as erecting suitable barriers, are taken.
type_sub_cat: Wearing Masks inside All or unspecified businesses
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: From August 28, the Swiss canton of Fribourg introduced the compulsory wearing of masks for persons above the age of 12 years in all shops and supermarkets. Exempt from this rule are employees that are separated through a (glass) barrier, as well as people sitting in restaurants or bars. The latter, however, still have to comply with the preventive measures for public hospitality venues.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: From August 28 2020, the Swiss canton of Fribourg introduced the compulsory wearing of face masks for all employees of catering institutions, i.e. restaurants, events with catering, bars, and dance clubs. This policy was announced on the 26th of August 2020.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: 26th August, 2020, the State Council of the Swiss Canton of Fribourg is strengthening the requirements for wearing a mask. Before, it was only strongly recommended to wear masks in supermarkets and shops, but now customers and staff must wear a mask. For places such as restaurants, events with service, bars and nightclubs, only service staff is concerned. Those measures will start on the 28th August, 2020.
type_sub_cat: Wearing Masks in all public spaces/everywhere
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Provincial/State Government,Municipal Government,Police

description: From August 28, the Swiss canton of Fribourg introduced the compulsory wearing of face masks for all employees of catering institutions, i.e. restaurants, events with catering, bars, and dance clubs. UPDATE: The policy ended with the new federal rule, making masks mandatory in all public establishments from the 19th of October 2020.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: The Council of State of Valais Switzerland has decided to strengthen measures to protect the population against the COVID-19 pandemic. On Monday 31 August 2020, wearing a mask and providing hydro-alcoholic solutions for customers will be compulsory in Valais in all closed indoor shops and businesses.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: Beginning on September 3, 2020, the Swiss canton of Solothurn requires the wearing of face masks in all retail stores and shopping centers. Exempt are children under the age of 12, people who must not wear a mask for medical reasons (if carrying a written certificate by a doctor), as well as staff, if protected by a physical barrier.

description: On September 15th 2020, the Swiss Canton of Vaud announced mandatory mask wearing for all indoor public spaces until the 30th of September 2020. Indoor spaces include cafés, bars, restaurants, theatres, cinemas, hotels, libraries and concert halls. All employees and clients need to wear a masks. In restaurants, it is only allowed to take off the mask whilst sitting. Children under 12 years old are exempt for this obligation.
type_sub_cat: Wearing Masks inside Unspecified public facilities
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: Zurich (Switzerland) implements a mask obligation in businesses from August 27 until Septmber 30. The following persons are exempted from this requirement: children under the age of 12; persons who can prove that they are unable to wear face masks for compelling reasons, in particular medical reasons; employees, if effective protective measures, such as erecting suitable barriers, are taken. UPDATE: The original mask obligation in businesses was set to last until September 30, it has been extended to October 31.
type_sub_cat: Wearing Masks inside All or unspecified businesses
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On 19th August 2020, the Swiss canton of Neuchâtel announced that mask wearing would be mandatory in enclosed shops with a capacity of more than 10 people (staff included) and malls. The following businesses are exempted from this measure: shops with a floor space of maximum 80m2, places which involve sports activities, banks and post offices. This measure enters into force on 21st August 2020 and will last until 30th September 2020. On 10th September 2020, the canton announced that this measure would be extended until 30th November 2020. UPDATE: The original policy was set to end on 30th September 2020 and it has been extended to 30th November 2020.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: The canton Zurich in Switzerland implements a mask obligation for service personnel in gastronomic businesses as well as for service personnel at events. The policy starts on the 15th of october 2020 and is supposed to end on the 31th of october 2020.

description: The goverment of the Swiss Canton Grisons announced on October 16, 2020 in all secondary schools II/2 (age 16 and older) masks will be mandatory for all persons on the school ground. Only in class rooms the masks can be taken off, if there is enough distance (1,5meters) between each person or physical barriers like plexiglass. If not, masks are mandatory for  teachers in class rooms. In all other schools masks will be mandatory for all adults. Exceptions are only possible for special need schools after consultation with the Cantonal doctor. This measure takes effect starting October 17, 2020.
type_sub_cat: Wearing Masks inside Secondary Schools (generally for children ages 10 to 18)
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On October 16, 2020 the goverment of the Swiss Canton Grisons announced that masks will be mandatory in "public facilities" for all persons over the age of 12, starting October 17, 2020. Shops, shopping centers, post offices, museums, theaters, administrative buildings, places of worship and religious common rooms, cinemas, train stations, libraries, hotels, restaurants are affected by this measure. In restaurants (including bars, clubs, discos etc.) masks only can be taken off, when you are sitting at a table. Only sport and fitness facilites and occuring persons like artists or athletes are excluded from this measure.

description: The Swiss Canton Saint Gallen announced on October 16, 2020 that the measures in restaurants, bars and clubs will be restricted. From October 17, 2020 on masks will be mandatory for the staff, the consumption of food and beverages will only be allowed when you're sitting at a table. This measure is applicable until December 31, 2020. UPDATE: This Policy ends earlier, on December 21, 2020, as all restaurant, bar, club, discotheque and dance venues are closed nationally from December 22, 2020.

description:
In the canton of Zurich (Switzerland), a general masking requirement for adults (teaching and school staff, members of the authorities, parents and third parties) will apply at schools (in school buildings, sports halls, care rooms and break areas) from October 19, 2020 until presumably December 31, 2020. The mask obligation also applies to pupils as well as apprentices at the "Sekundarstufe II" and students of the tertiary level B. Exception: If during lessons the minimum distance of 1.5 meters to other persons is maintained or if protection can be ensured by sufficient protective measures, such as Plexiglas walls, adults don't have to wear a mask. 
The framework for the protection concepts of educational institutions established by the Government Council in its decision of July 8, 2020, shall continue to apply.
type_sub_cat: Wearing Masks inside Primary Schools (generally for children ages 10 and below)
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries
enforcer: Ministry/Department of Health,Ministry/Department of Education,Provincial/State Government,Municipal Government,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description: Beginning on September 3, 2020, the Swiss canton of Solothurn requires the wearing of face masks in all retail stores and shopping centers. Exempt are children under the age of 12, people who must not wear a mask for medical reasons (if carrying a written certificate by a doctor), as well as staff, if protected by a physical barrier. UPDATE: Declared obsolete due to equivalent federal regulations from October 19.

description: On October 15, 2020, the cantonal government of Thurgau announces that from October 23, 2020 onwards, it is obligatory to wear a protective face mask at public and private events with 30 or more persons. Exceptions to this rule apply to children up to the age of 12 years, for persons who can prove that they cannot wear a mask for medical, reasons, for personnel, if they are protected by a physical barrier (e.g. plexiglass), as well as for performers (artists, sportsmen and sportswomen, etc.). The consumption of food and beverages is permitted exclusively in the seating areas provided for this purpose.

description: The education department of the Swiss Cantion Saint Gallen announced on October 30, 2020 that masks will be mandatory in high schools ("Oberstufe", age 16-18) starting from November 2,2020. In other schools masks are already mandatory, but there it was ordered by the federal government. The masks will be mandatory on the whole school ground and during classes. Also singing should be avoided. While so called contact sports like soccer or basketball are already prohibited by the federal government, the provincial education department now also orders that the physical education classes must be cut in half if it does not take place outside with social distancing measures. If a student had contact to a positive-tested person and couldn't keep the minimum distance or wear a mask he is also under quarantine.
type_sub_cat: Wearing Masks inside Secondary Schools (generally for children ages 10 to 18)
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On November 3, 2020 in Switzerland Canton Grisons announced that masks will be mandatory in secondary schools I (age 13-16) starting November 9, 2020. Masks will be mandatory for students and teachers in private and public schools on the entire school grounds. Exceptions are only possible for special needs schools after consultation with the Canton doctor. This applies until December 22, 2020, the start of the Christmas holidays.
type_sub_cat: Wearing Masks inside Secondary Schools (generally for children ages 10 to 18)

description: On December 9, 2020 the Swiss Canton Saint Gallen announced that residents of retirement facilities are still allowed to welcome to visitors per day but it is only allowed to meet in the lobby, foyer or cafeteria, meetings in private rooms are prohibited. This measure should relieve the compliance of the social distancing restrictions and the employees of the facilities.

description: On February 10, 2021 the government of the Swiss Canton Grisons announced that starting from February 11, 2021 masks will be mandatory for all students of the 5th and 6th grade (Primärklassen; age 10-12) on the whole school area. Exceptions are only possible for special need schools after consultation with the Cantonal doctor

description: On March 3, 2021, the health department of the Swiss canton of Graubünden decided that the visiting and mask wearing regulations in retirement and nursing homes and facilities should be relaxed for all residents who received their second vaccination at least 15 days ago. You no longer have to wear masks (this also applies to employees), everyone who has not received their second vaccination or 15 days have not passed since the second vaccination must wear masks. All those who received their second vaccination during the last 15 days or before are also allowed to receive visitors (up to 2 persons). The visitors have to wear masks. The visitors of residents whose vaccination was during the last 15days are only allowed to meet in the rooms or cantina. Residents who got their second vaccination at least 15 days or more before  have no any spatial regulations for their visits. For residents who got no vaccination the measures are still applicable.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries
